children.name: Maps of The Holy Land in the Eran Laor collection
children.data:
From ancient times the Holy Land has been the focus of great attraction for both Jews and Christians and Muslims. Throughout the ages Jews and Christians have made pilgrimages to the Holy Land, envisaged scenes and stories from the Scriptures, and dreamt of it from afar. Many of them left behind them descriptions and studies of the Holy Land accompanied by views and drawings.

The Eran Laor map collection in the National Library of Israel contains about 1500 maps of Jerusalem and of the Holy Land from the beginning of print up to our days.

attachments.name: Civitas Hierusalem, Bertelli, Donato,  Venice, 16th century [156- ].jpg
Hierusalem, Du Perac,  Stefano . Roma, c.1570.jpg

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land
children.data: Depictions of the Holy Land appeared mostly in Bibles, in travel books, and in histories and geographies. With the invention of the printing press it became worthwhile to produce large and detailed drawings which were then printed in several editions. These drawings are often called maps, although they were really often rather naïve and romantic impressions. Diachronic in nature, they often record events from the past and the future on one map. Favored scenes are the land as promised to Abraham, or Jerusalem in the time of Jesus. The readers were thus introduced to this unique site where momentous events occurred and are yet to occur in the future.

attachments.name: Palestinae sive totius Terrae Promissionis, Ortelius,  Stella and van Diest, 1575.jpg
attachments.location: AE0BA84A-88FB-0EC6-25D5-BDD81F99F748\Palestinae sive totius Terrae Promissionis, Ortelius,  Stella and van Diest, 1575.jpg

parent.name: Maps of The Holy Land in the Eran Laor collection

children.name: Adrichom's Map of Jerusalem
children.data: Christian van Adrichom was a Catholic priest and theologian. A native of Delft, he fled to Cologne  in the wake of the religious turmoil of the Reformation. His map of Jerusalem is part of his book, published in 1584, on the antiquities and history of the Holy Land and is based on the Bible, Josephus Flavius, and many other sources. Purporting to depict Jerusalem in the time of Jesus, it includes a variety of illustrations representing sundry historical periods. Adrichom's map was one of the most popular and influential maps of the period and was often copied.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Biblical Scenes in Adrichom's map
children.data: Biblical Scenes are represented widely in Adrichom's map:

children.name: :1: King David's palace
children.data: The palace of King David and above it Bathsheba, the future mother of King Solomon, bathing on the roof near the palace.

children.name: :2: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple
children.data: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple depicted in detail: The Temple Courtyard drawn according to Josephus' description, the Ark and the Cherubim, the High Priest, the Candelabrum and the Table of the Showbread, as well as the Sacrificial Altar in front of the Temple.
children.chronologicalName: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple

children.name: :3: The shrine of the idol Moloch
children.data: The Temple of the Ammonite idol Moloch that King Solomon built in the Valley of Gehena (I Kings: 11:7).  According to the Bible (I Kings 16:3; 21:6), the kings of Judah Ahaz and Manasseh took part in the Moloch ritual by passing their sons through the fire. At the bottom, the sawing of the tree where the Prophet Isaiah was hidden by the slaves of the wicked king Manasseh, and Isaiah's sepulcher are depicted.
children.chronologicalName: The shrine of the idol Moloch

children.name: :4: The Babylonian army camp
children.data: The camp of the Babylonian army besieging Jerusalem on the eve of the destruction of the First Temple.

children.name: The Via Dolorosa
children.data: The Via Dolorosa of Jesus, from his trial to his Crucifixion is depicted in detail in Adrichom's map.

children.name: :1: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace
children.data: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace where the Trial of Jesus takes place and Pilate declares: "Crucifige".
children.chronologicalName: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace

children.name: :2: The Via Dolorosa
children.data: The Via Dolorosa – Jesus is commanded to carry the Cross, he falls, and is then assisted by Simon of Cyrene.

children.name: :3: The Crucifixion
children.data: The Crucifixion of Jesus and the two thieves, the two Marys standing under the cross, Jesus being taken down from the Cross and buried, and the Resurrection.

children.name: Ortelius' Map
children.data:
This map was made by the famous publisher, Abraham Ortelius active in the Low Countries during the 16th century who, in an age of great geographical discoveries was the first to print a modern atlas. Although a "modern" cartographer at the time, Ortelius dedicated a special map to "The Life and Peregrination of the Patriarch Abraham to the Promised Land".  

The biblical passage (Genesis 12: 1-2) commanding Abraham to leave on the journey appears along the top frame of the map:  “Go from your country, your people and your father’s household to the land I will show you", while on the bottom appears Genesis 17:8: "The whole land of Canaan, where you now reside as a foreigner, I will give as an everlasting possession to you and your descendants after you ."

attachments.name: Ortelius Cartouch and top biblical passage.jpg

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems
children.data:
The most captivating feature in this map are the picture emblems which tell the story of Abraham:

Abraham's family led by Abraham and his father Terah, are commanded by God to leave Haran for the Promised Land (Genesis 11:31).

children.name: :1: The altar at Beth-El
children.data: After returning to Canaan from Egypt Abraham builds an altar in Beth-El where God appeared to him and promised to give the land to him and to his descendants. (Genesis 13:1-12)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :2: Abraham and Melchizedek
children.data: After defeating the rebellious kings in the Valley of Siddim Abraham (kneeling in his armour) is met by Melchizedek king of Shalem (the future Jerusalem) and priest to the Most High God, who offers him bread and wine and gives him a blessing. (Genesis 14:18-20)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :3: The Covenant of the Parts
children.data: Having promised Abraham as many descendants as the stars, God promises the land to Abraham through theCovenant of the Parts. On the right: God is standing behind Abraham, while Abraham's servant prepares the animals for sacrifice. On the left: the covenant is sealed by a burning torch, the divine fire consuming Abraham's sacrifice. (Genesis 15)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :4: Sarah gives Abraham her slave-girl
children.data: When Sarah despairs of having a child, she gives Abraham her slave-girl so that she may bear him a child. (Genesis 16)

attachments.name: Ortelius Sarah gives Abraham her slave-girl.jpg

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :5: The three angels
children.data: Abraham is visited by the three angels. While offering them a place to rest and water to wash  their feet, he is given the surprising tidings that he and Sarah will soon have a child. Sarah is seen in the background preparing the calf. (Genesis 18)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :6: Birth of Isaac
children.data: Sarah is giving birth to Isaac. The new-born baby is being held by the midwife while the maids assist Sarah. (Genesis 21:1-6).

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :7: Abraham banishes Hagar and Ishma'el
children.data: After Isaac is born, Abraham sends Hagar away with Ishma'el while the feast in honour of the newborn Isaac is taking place in the background. The protecting angel hovers above the scene. (Genesis 21:8-11)

attachments.name: Ortelius Banishment of Hagar and Ishma'el.jpg

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :8: The sacrifice of Isaac
children.data: The Sacrifice of Isaac: on the right Abraham prays asking God to annul this terrible decree, while on the left he is raising the knife when his gaze is guided by the angel towards the ram which he his commanded to offer in Isaac's stead.  (Genesis 22)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :9: Abraham's death
children.data: Abraham's Death: Abraham is being lowered into the grave in the Cave of the Makhpela to be buried beside Sarah. (Genesis 25)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: Journeys to Jerusalem
children.data: Christians throughout the ages were drawn to Jerusalem, captivated by its glorious past: it was the city into which according to Christian tradition Jesus made his Triumphal Entry, the stage upon which the events of the Great Week took place, and the place of his Crucifixion and Resurrection and the Ascension. It was also the city of David and Solomon and the setting of a multitude of biblical events. Although many pilgrims and scholars purported to depict "modern" Jerusalem, their maps often followed much earlier maps, and their main aim was to map out the Christian sites, usually ignoring the Muslim presence in the city.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: :1: Daumont's Map
children.data:
Jean François Daumont made this beautiful map of Jerusalem in 1780. However, it was actually copied from a map originally drawn almost 300 years beforehand, in 1486, following the pilgrimage of Bernhard of Breydenbach to Jerusalem in 1483.

Daumont marks Christian and Muslim monuments with a cross or crescent, but does not name the Muslim monuments. In fact, Daumont chooses to call the mosques on the Temple Mount by their Crusader name: "Templum Salomonis", preferring history to reality.

children.name: :2: Braun and Hogenberg's map
children.data:
This view of Jerusalem was one of three maps of the city included in the famous city atlas compiled by Braun and Hoghenberg, in 1575. The quotation from Ezek. 5:5 at the top of the map conveys the idea of Jerusalem as the center of the earth, while the citation from Pliny the Elder on the bottom left lauds "Jerusalem, the most famous of the cities in the Orient, Metropolis of Judaea".

The city is seen here from the perspective of pilgrims standing on the Mount of Olives, looking eastwards. Although the round shape of the city is schematic, there are various realistic elements such as the citadel in the background, the bridges over the Kidron valley and the blocked doorway to the church of the Holy Sepulcher.

attachments.name: Jerusalem, Hogenberg,  Braun and Jansson, Amsterdam, 1657.jpg

children.name: :3: Dapper's map
children.data:
Dapper (1635-1689), who never travelled outside Holland, collected a lot of information about the Holy Land and many other countries. His realistic map (1677) relied on the map made by Bernardino Amico, a Franciscan monk in Jerusalem between1593-1597. Amico, in fact, copied a map made by another Franciscan monk, Antonio d'Angelis, who had served in Jerusalem a few years before; his map continued to be copied by generations of Christian map-makers.

The map does not identify the religious affiliation of the monuments with a cross or crescent, and calls the mosques on the Temple Mount – "The Pagan Church".

attachments.name: Jerusalem,  Dapper, Amsterdam 1677 'De Stadt Ierusalem zoot Hedendaeghs Bevonden wordt'.jpg
attachments.location: 62CF2583-19FF-9B73-7ED2-2E3C833E1F7F\Jerusalem,  Dapper, Amsterdam 1677 'De Stadt Ierusalem zoot Hedendaeghs Bevonden wordt'.jpg

children.name: :4: Mondhare's Map
children.data: This landscape drawn by L. Mondhare in 1770, portrays Ottoman Jerusalem as a city commanded by towering minarets and crescents in a surreal mixture of imagination and reality. Prominently situated towards the left of the map is the Dome of the Rock while in the center the Church of the Holy Sepulcher stands out clearly. At the front of the sketch is the Kidron River, usually a dry riverbed, appearing as a broad, rushing, European style river. The inscription at the bottom states that the City of David and Solomon is currently controlled by the Ottomans and notes the existence of a Franciscan monastery within the city.

attachments.name: Jerusalem, Mondhare,  Paris 1770, 'Jerusalem Ville Capitale de la Palestine sous David et Salomon'.jpg
attachments.location: F1A2E200-3903-B57D-F9ED-561C9A606EB0\Jerusalem, Mondhare,  Paris 1770, 'Jerusalem Ville Capitale de la Palestine sous David et Salomon'.jpg

children.name: A Dutch Map
children.data: This map was drawn in the Netherlands, following Ortelius's map of the Holy Land around 1600. The anonymous artist added to Ortelius' map a series of illustrations, including Jonah being tossed to the mouth of the big fish and Israelite figures crossing the desert. At the bottom right the twelve tribes are encamped in the Sinai Desert, and on the bottom right the Grotto of the Nativity in Bethlehem is depicted. Interestingly, the North in the compass rose is pointing to the south!

attachments.name: Palestine, Dutch, beginning of 17th century, 'De Caerte vant theylich land..'.jpg
attachments.location: 0711F4D9-F275-9116-0C43-AE1B48ADAD97\Palestine, Dutch, beginning of 17th century, 'De Caerte vant theylich land..'.jpg

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Seutter's Map
children.data: Matthaeus Seutter's map of Palestine was part of his atlas, which was popular in Europe in the 18th century. The map, based on a prototype made a century earlier by Sanson, aims to depict the Holy Land to the Christian European audience from the First Temple until the Roman period, covering the period of the events told in the Old and New Testament. Equally important, is the scene on the top left, showing Jesus exorcising a demon, watched from above by God and the Holy Spirit, with the Crucifixion in the background. On the bottom right the route of the Exodus from Egypt is depicted separately.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Blaeu's Map
children.data:
In 1629, W.J. Blaeu printed a new world atlas containing 45 maps. One of these was a map of the Holy Land as seen by Moses from Mt. Nevo just before his death and after forty years of wandering with the Israelites in the desert.

The cartouche on the bottom right is surrounded by the figures of Moses and Aaron. In this image, Moses had just descended from Mt. Sinai with the Tablets and is shown according to Jerome's mistaken translation of Exodus 34:29, with horns over his head. Next to him stands Aaron, the High Priest, in his special attire and paraphernalia.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: :1: The Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert
children.data: The story of Moses and the Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert is shown here in miniature drawings: on the left the Children of Israel are seen crossing the parted Red Sea, their following route through the desert being marked by a yellow trail. On the right the revelation at Mount Sinai, as well as the Tabernacle and the various camps of the Israelites are depicted.
children.chronologicalName: The Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert

children.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes
children.data: Jewish maps, though few and far between, represent the centrality of the Land of Israel in the history and hopes of the Jewish people. Traditional Jewish maps reflect two distinct trends in cartographic tradition: one group of maps follows  the original maps made by the prominent Bible commentator Rashi, while another follows Christian map models adapted to Jewish notions.

attachments.name: Map of The Land Israel,  Showing the Wanderings of the Israelites in the Desert,  Abraham ben Jacob, 17th cent.jpg
attachments.location: 03BA7521-8885-B14D-345A-0440CB69EB04\Map of The Land Israel,  Showing the Wanderings of the Israelites in the Desert,  Abraham ben Jacob, 17th cent.jpg

parent.name: Maps of The Holy Land in the Eran Laor collection

children.name: The Land of Israel -  European  Inspirations

parent.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes

children.name: :1: Shlomo of Helm's Map of the Land of Israel
children.data:
R. Shlomo of Helm (1717-1781) was a famous Jewish scholar and Rabbi in Poland. Although he was famous for his erudition in Jewish sources and law (Halakha), he chose extraordinarily to emphasize the importance of the study of Philosophy and Sciences alongside Jewish studies.

In the autograph manuscript of his book "Hug Ha-Aretz", recently purchased by the NLI, written in beautiful classical Hebrew language and in handsome calligraphic script, R. Shlomo drew a series of maps of the Land of Israel divided among the Tribes. Unlike the tradition following Rashi's maps, the legends in his maps prove that he was clearly inspired by the Christian maps of the Holy Land made by Adrichom and by Seutter.
children.chronologicalName: Shlomo of Helm's Map of the Land of Israel

parent.name: The Land of Israel -  European  Inspirations

children.name: :2: Schottlaender's map: A Harbinger of Zionism
children.data:
This lithograph, printed by Schottlaender in Breslau around 1900, is the last in a long line of maps, or tables, depicting Jewish pilgrimage sites and tombs of righteous men in the Holy Land. It is special in that it chooses to present only the most significant holy sites, omitting the rest. In their stead, the author elects to show the new colonies just established by Jews thus blending traditional views with the new Zionist movement!

The most prominent settlement in the map is Jerusalem; Safed appears above, to its left surrounded by many sacred tombs. The new Zionistic settlements are identified by the author as "colonie".

attachments.name: Panorama des heiligen landes, Schottlaender,  Breslau, 190-,  pal1134_b.jpg
attachments.location: 29A593B8-3FE8-D682-F394-B2EEC29B7D99\Panorama des heiligen landes, Schottlaender,  Breslau, 190-,  pal1134_b.jpg

children.chronologicalName: Schottlaender's map: A Harbinger of Zionism

parent.name: The Land of Israel -  European  Inspirations

children.name: The Land of Israel – the  Jewish Tradition
children.data:
This lovely hand-drawn map was drawn in the 19th century by an artist who claims that he copied it from the famous Jewish scholar, the Vilna Gaon (1720-1797).

The map follows an ancient tradition of mapping the borders of Land of Israel, as described in Numbers 34. This tradition commenced with Rashi, the greatest Jewish Biblical commentator, who lived in France in the 11th century.

Later tradition added the allotments of the 12 tribes, and cities and settlements which are represented here as European houses with tiled roofs. Jerusalem is depicted prominently with a tower beside it bearing the inscription "The Temple".

attachments.name: Palestine,  biblical borders and allotments of the tribes of Israel, mid nineteenth century.jpg
attachments.location: 6D3C4593-7543-E128-8DAC-F2605F00061D\Palestine,  biblical borders and allotments of the tribes of Israel, mid nineteenth century.jpg

parent.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes

children.name: Maimonides' Commentary on the Mishnah
children.data:
Moses Maimonides (born Cordoba 1138 – d. Cairo 1204) is considered one of the greatest Jewish scholars and intellectuals of all times.

Maimonides was first and foremost a preeminent interpreter of Jewish law (Halakah), producing groundbreaking legal codes, commentaries and wide-ranging legal opinions as leader of numerous Jewish communities. Yet was also a widely influential philosopher,  and physician, famous  throughout Jewish, Muslim and Christian intellectual circles of his time.  Maimonides constantly strove to reconcile his knowledge of philosophy and science with Jewish law and theology. 

Due both to his impressive intellectual horizons and to his outstanding influence among Jews and non-Jews Maimonides was known in Jewish tradition as The Great Eagle.

Maimonides' personal biography is representative of the fate of Spanish Jews at that time: born in Cordoba, where he absorbed Islamic science and culture, he fled from the intolerant Almohads  to Morocco and then to Fustat (Cairo) in Egypt, where he received the patronage of the Ayyubid court.

attachments.name: Maimonides' portrait from the Thesaurus antiquitatum sacrarum, 1744.jpg
attachments.location: E07DE180-4F9F-F5EF-5597-F1B13CA9F5B3\Maimonides' portrait from the Thesaurus antiquitatum sacrarum, 1744.jpg

attachments.name: Copy of Maimonides, a marble relief at Capitol hill, Washington, artist - Brenda Putnam.jpg
attachments.location: E07DE180-4F9F-F5EF-5597-F1B13CA9F5B3\Copy of Maimonides, a marble relief at Capitol hill, Washington, artist - Brenda Putnam.jpg

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: Commentary on the Mishnah
children.data:
As in other scholarly fields, Maimonides broke new ground to write a commentary directly on the Mishnah.  Maimonides began composing his commentary  in 1161 while living in in Morocco and completed it in Egypt in 1168. The NLI owns an autograph, that is one of the unique manuscripts written in Maimonides' own hand, of two parts, Nashim, and Mo'ed.

 

Photographs: This is a page from Seder Mo'ed –"Festival" . Although this is already a "clean" copy, one can see here many changes. The large number of notes and corrections in the autograph, are evidence of  Maimonides' dynamic thinking and constant development.  Maimonides was an original philosopher and thinker who never ceased to ask questions and to improve his works. 

The Commentary remained in the use of the family and in the books in the NLI there are notes which were made by Maimonides' son Abraham, and his grandson David, both of whom were scholars and leaders of the community.

attachments.name: Maimonides, Seder Mo'ed, Autograph, Page 72, details, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: 4504BA63-8A03-E369-3B65-6AA7A2D71392\Maimonides, Seder Mo'ed, Autograph, Page 72, details, NLI.jpg

attachments.name: Maimonides, Seder Mo'ed, Autograph, Page 72, NLI.jpg

children.name: :_: What is the Mishnah?
children.data:
Alongside the Torah (the Pentateuch), which is the written  law of the Jews,  there developed an oral tradition of interpretation. This tradition was put down in writing and sealed in the beginning of the third century CE by Rabbi Yehudah Ha-Nassi , the head of the Jewish  Assembly, since it was feared at that time that the tradition would be lost. The Mishnah is considered to be a source of religious legal authority second only to the written Torah.

photograph: A paragraph from the Mishnah, preserved in the Cairo Genizah: "Rabbi Yohanan said: Whoever fulfills the Torah despite poverty, will ultimately fulfill it in wealth; but whoever neglects the Torah because of wealth, will ultimately neglect it in poverty."

attachments.name: Mishnah, Seder Nezikin, Masekhet Avot, from the Cairo Genizah, detail, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: F7473840-FD1D-D51D-F9E9-E5C0737401F5\Mishnah, Seder Nezikin, Masekhet Avot, from the Cairo Genizah, detail, NLI.jpg

children.name: :_: What is the Talmud?
children.data:
Talmud (literally "study, learning"), the central text of rabbinic Judaism, has influenced the lives of Jews no less, and perhaps much more than the Hebrew Bible. For several hundred years, Jewish rabbis in academies in Palestine and in Babylonians studied the Mishnah. Their discussions were recorded in the Talmud (6th century). These include a wide variety of subjects pertaining to Halakhah (Jewish law) and ethics, philosophy and history, to mention just a few. Jewish scholars thus interpreted the Mishna primarily through the lens of the Talmud. 

The most popular and influential version of the Talmud is the Babylonian one, although a Palestinian version exists as well.

The Talmud, written inHebrew and Aramaic become the legal authority in rabbinic Judaism and is the basis for Jewish legal discourse.

children.name: The language of the Commentary
children.data: The commentary was written in Judeo-Arabic , a dialect of Arabic that was spoken by Jews  living in the Arabic speaking world from the eighth century onwards, and is still spoken by some Jews today.  Although the language was Arabic, it was written in Hebrew letters. Many of the great medieval works of Jewish law and thought were written in Judeo-Arabic.

attachments.name: Learning to read the Hebrew letters in Judeo-Arabic dialect, Yemen.mp3
attachments.location: 7505D43F-518B-4B46-4495-45B81531F2A9\Learning to read the Hebrew letters in Judeo-Arabic dialect, Yemen.mp3

attachments.name: Sa'adiah Gaon, Kitāb ul-ʾamānāt wal-iʿtiqādāt (Book of Beliefs and Opinions), NLI.jpg
attachments.location: 7505D43F-518B-4B46-4495-45B81531F2A9\Sa'adiah Gaon, Kitāb ul-ʾamānāt wal-iʿtiqādāt (Book of Beliefs and Opinions), NLI.jpg

children.name: :2: From Egypt to Aleppo
children.data: After Maimonides' death the manuscript remained in the hands of the family in Egypt for several generations. When in 1375, due to the persecutions of Jews in Egypt,  the descendants of Maimonides moved to Aleppo in Syria

children.name: :3: The Library in Aleppo
children.data: The Mishnah Commentary remained in the hands of the family in Aleppo along with other precious manuscripts for several generations.  The family encouraged the Jews in Aleppo to make authorized copies of the manuscripts in the library.

attachments.name: A model of the Aleppo Synagogue, Beit Hatfutsot, Museum of the Jewish People, Tel Aviv, Israel.jpg
attachments.location: 0364CF7B-3F0B-C121-C39B-5D4439E226F6\A model of the Aleppo Synagogue, Beit Hatfutsot, Museum of the Jewish People, Tel Aviv, Israel.jpg

children.name: :4: The Arrival of the Spanish Jews and the Dispersal of the Library
children.data: With the arrival of the Jews who had been expelled from Spain in 1492, interest in Maimonides' writings declined, and the Spanish Jewish tradition of Kabbalah and mysticism started to flourish.  By the 17th century the library’s contents had been dispersed.

attachments.name: Portae Lucis, Latin translation of Gikatilla's Kabbalistic work Shaarei Ora - Gates of Light.jpg
attachments.location: 1E9B1ED7-FC05-8624-14CD-02272D8B60A1\Portae Lucis, Latin translation of Gikatilla's Kabbalistic work Shaarei Ora - Gates of Light.jpg

children.chronologicalName: The Arrival of the Spanish Jews and the Dispersal of the Library

children.name: :5: From Aleppo to the NLI
children.data:
In the 17th century, when Christian scholars became interested in Hebrew manuscripts, three of the six volumes were purchased in Aleppo by European scholars and were later sold to the Bodleian Library in Oxford.

The other volumes remained  in Aleppo, and then found their way to Damascus. There, two volumes  were found in terrible condition; the  Bodleian Library refused to buy them in this state. Luckily, they were purchased and conserved by the bibliophile Sassoon family from whom they were purchased by the NLI in 1975. 

The sixth volume of the Commentary written Maimonides' own hand is still missing, but perhaps it will one day surface!

attachments.name: Maimonides' Code of Jewish Law at The Bodleian Library
Maimonides at the NLI website - the Great Eagle exhibition

children.name: An Extraordinary Life Story
children.data:
Maimonides' amazing life story starts in the multicultural world of Cordoba and ends in the King's court in Cairo.

Photograph: an official medal of the state of Israel, honouring Maimonides' 800th anniversary, showing the various stations of Maimonides life across the Mediterranean.

attachments.name: Official medal of the state of Israel honouring Maimonides' 800th anniversary, Israel Coins and Medals Corporation.jpg
attachments.location: B45441E4-0097-0317-6BDB-FD5F59E44DDA\Official medal of the state of Israel honouring Maimonides' 800th anniversary, Israel Coins and Medals Corporation.jpg

children.name: :1: Maimonides in Cordoba
children.data: Born in Cordoba in 1138, Maimonides grew up during  the rule of the Berber dynasty  of the Murabitun (Almoravids). Under their rule the Jewish and the Christian communities were protected according to Muslim law.

attachments.name: Maimonides' statue in the Jewish quarter of Cordoba.jpg
attachments.location: 6BCDA941-C0D4-3E08-7823-4101211A63A8\Maimonides' statue in the Jewish quarter of Cordoba.jpg

children.name: :2: Master of Jewish Law, Mathematics, Philosophy, Theology, and Medicine
children.data:
In medieval Spain, these sciences were components of a curriculum shared by young  Jewish and Muslim scholars of the educated classes who were part of a lively intellectual milieu.  It was during this period that he mentions having met the famous Muslim mathematician and astronomer Jabir b. Aflah al-Ishbili. 

In these early years he wrote treatises on Logic, and on Geometry and Optics.

attachments.name: Jabir ibn Aflah, Europe, 16th century, wood engraving, university of Pennsylvania library.jpg
attachments.location: DF6089D1-D5E1-82D5-A31D-1B98BE878817\Jabir ibn Aflah, Europe, 16th century, wood engraving, university of Pennsylvania library.jpg

attachments.name: The Coppenhagen manuscript of Maimonides' Guide for the Preplexed,  illuminated in Catalonia, the Danish royal library website
Maimonides' Hanhagat ha-Beri'ut (medical treatise), Florence 1481, NLI.jpg
Maimonides' logica Sapientis Rabbi Simeonis, Latin translation, Basel 1527, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: DF6089D1-D5E1-82D5-A31D-1B98BE878817\Maimonides' logica Sapientis Rabbi Simeonis, Latin translation, Basel 1527, NLI.jpg

children.chronologicalName: Master of Jewish Law, Mathematics, Philosophy, Theology, and Medicine

children.name: :3: Intellectual Milieu and Influences
children.data: Maimonides was greatly influenced by Muslim philosophers who combined Aristotelian and Neoplatonic philosophy, such as Farabi, Ibn Sina  (Avicenna),  and the Spanish Ibn Bajja (Avempace) (Zaragoza 1095-1138). Maimonides’ writings influenced the great Christian scholastic theologians such as Aquinas and Albertus Magnus,  and, in later centuries , Spinoza and Leibnitz.

attachments.name: Opening decoration and invocation to Allah, a 16th century manuscript of Avicenna's Canon, Yale university.jpg
attachments.location: E1888FC1-0603-B624-13D6-938AB577AFEC\Opening decoration and invocation to Allah, a 16th century manuscript of Avicenna's Canon, Yale university.jpg

children.name: :4: The Family is Forced to Leave Cordoba
children.data: In 1148 Cordoba was taken over by the intolerant dynasty of the Muwahhidun (Almohads), who by then ruled most of the Maghreb as well. The Almohads deprived the non-Muslim communities of their previous rights and persecuted them with threats of forced conversion or deportation. The Maimonides family, like many others, left Cordoba and began an extended period of wandering.

attachments.name: coin of Muwahidun ruler abd al-Mu'min (1094–1163).jpg

children.chronologicalName: The Family is Forced to Leave Cordoba

children.name: :5: 1160-1165 Morocco - Forced Conversion
children.data:
In 1160 the family settled in Fez, Morocco which was also under the rule of the Almohads as well, where Maimonides witnessed terrible persecutions. It seems that during this period the family was forced to convert.

This is probably why sometime between 1160-1165 Maimonides wrote The Letter on Forced Conversions  which pardoned fake conversion to Islam in cases of forced conversion. In Fez Maimonides continued studying medicine, mainly through apprenticeship.

attachments.name: Iggeret hashmad (letter on forced conversion), Abraham Geiger's edition, Breslau, 1850.jpg
attachments.location: FD78C210-0204-98D5-380D-23FB99FBAFC1\Iggeret hashmad (letter on forced conversion), Abraham Geiger's edition, Breslau, 1850.jpg

children.name: :6: Pilgrimage to the Holy Land
children.data: In 1165 the Maimonides' family left for Palestine, which was ruled at that time by the Crusaders. They visited  Acre, Jerusalem and Hebron.

attachments.name: Acre map, Vesconte, Petrus, 17th century, Civitas Acon Sive ptolomayda.jpg
attachments.location: A35916B5-7608-6F21-7BC9-A0335815B679\Acre map, Vesconte, Petrus, 17th century, Civitas Acon Sive ptolomayda.jpg

children.name: :7: The Family moves to Old Cairo (Fustat)
children.data: In 1166 the family settled in Fustat (old Cairo), then under Fatimid rule. The Fatimids were tolerant rulers, and their theology encouraged the study of philosophy. Maimonides, protected by the Fatimid rule, took to teaching Greek sciences and philosophy. During the first five years in Fustat, Maimonides completed his first major legal treatise, the Commentary on the Mishnah, a work that he composed over the long years of travels.
children.chronologicalName: The Family moves to Old Cairo (Fustat)

children.name: :8: Maimonides Becomes Court  Physician of the Ayyubids
children.data:
Maimonides' family made its living from commerce, and Maimonides was supported by his brother David who traded with India. In 1171 Egypt was conquered by the Ayyubid dynasty.  Around the same time Maimonides' brother David drowned during a commercial trip to India, and Maimonides, sick with grief over his brother, was forced to begin work as a court physician for the royal family.

During these years he wrote many important medical treatises, in which he sought to simplify and render more systematic the medical tradition of Galen (2nd century) transmitted through the Muslim world. His treatises were translated to Latin during the 13th century and thus influenced medical knowledge in the medieval West.

attachments.name: Maimonides, Hanhagat ha-Beri'ut (medical treatise), Latin translation, Florence 1481.jpg
attachments.location: AA3EB497-D1C2-9CA5-9B12-6CC4C0D9CBE5\Maimonides, Hanhagat ha-Beri'ut (medical treatise), Latin translation, Florence 1481.jpg

children.chronologicalName: Maimonides Becomes Court  Physician of the Ayyubids

children.name: :9: Appointed Head of the  Jewish Community
children.data:
During this period Maimonides was recognized as the highest spiritual authority of his time and served for some years also as head  of the Jewish community  in Egypt (Rais al-Yahud). His numerous legal and theological responses to queries from Jews in Egypt, the Middle East, and Europe attest to his local authority and international prestige.

The stability of Maimonides’ later life in Ayyubid Egypt enabled him to compose many treatises, including his two most important works: the Mishneh Torah  and the Guide to the Preplexed.

 

photographs: The Ben Ezra synagogue, the ancient synagogue in old Cairo (Fustat), where Maimonides led the Jewish liturgy, also shown are the works of preservation and construction
children.chronologicalName: Appointed Head of the  Jewish Community

children.name: :10: His Death
children.data:
Maimonides passed away in 1204 in Egypt and was buried there, but early Jewish tradition claims that he had asked to be buried in the Holy Land and that his boned were brought to burial in Tiberias, where his tomb is still shown.

A very known Hebrew proverb in Maimonides' memory is "From moses to Moses there was none as great as Moses", meaning that from the biblical Moses to Moses son of Maymon (Maimonides), no one was their match in the leadership of the Jewish people and the knowledge of the Torah. This proverb was inscribed on his grave at Tiberias.

attachments.name: Inscription on Maimonides' tomb at Tiberias - From moses to Moses there was none as great as Moses.jpg
attachments.location: 0E88C45C-353C-2D9C-D6C2-A2395A860B45\Inscription on Maimonides' tomb at Tiberias - From moses to Moses there was none as great as Moses.jpg

children.name: :1: The  Mishneh Torah
children.data: Following this composition, Maimonides wrote his most famous treatise called the Mishneh Torah, a comprehensive code of Jewish Law which is conceived throughout the Jewish world as one of the chief authoritative codifications of Jewish law and ethics, as well as other important writings. In this great composition Maimonides broke from one thousand years of legal precedent of writing commentaries to produce a systematic codification of Jewish law by subject. Although most of Maimonides’ treatises were written in Judeo-Arabic, Maimonides composed the Code in Hebrew to ensure its accessibility for Jews all over the world.The manuscript was copied in Spain between 1300-1350, and illustrated around 1400 in Perugia, by the artist Matteo Di Ser Cambio.

attachments.name: Maimonides, Mishneh Torah, Spain, 1300-1350, Detail, NLI.tif

children.name: :2: The NLI manuscript
children.data: Written between 1300-1350 in Spain, it is the most splendid illuminated copy known. Although copied in Spain, most of the illustrations were done in Perugia  Italy around 1400 in the studio of Matteo di Ser Cambio.

attachments.name: Maimonides, Mishneh Torah, Spain, with illustration, 1300-1350, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: 1BAF406E-CD39-9925-64F2-EB8CD3520C9E\Maimonides, Mishneh Torah, Spain, with illustration, 1300-1350, NLI.jpg

children.name: :3: The Guide of the Perplexed
children.data: The Guide of the Perplexed, an important philosophical treatise, which was composed between 1185-1191, is set as a letter to a young disciple. The Guide sought to resolve apparent contradictions between rationalist philosophy on the one hand, and Jewish tradition found in Scripture and the Talmud, on the other hand.  Unlike the Mishneh Torah, which was written for broad use, the Guide, written in Judeo-Arabic,  was written for a more limited audience of rationalist yet traditional Jews. A few of Maimonides’ theological positions led to public controversies with rabbinic leaders  outside of Egypt towards the end of his life.

attachments.name: Guide of the Preplexed, 14th century,  Yemen, Judeo-Arabic, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: FB6C82E3-22BC-35F8-A367-5AAB2732BB40\Guide of the Preplexed, 14th century,  Yemen, Judeo-Arabic, NLI.jpg

children.name: Zweig, Benjamin, Kafka: Comets in the Sky of German Culture
children.data: In a gradual process which began in the last quarter of the 19th century, and  continued until the rise of the Nazis, Jews in the German-speaking world had made a transition from exclusion to acceptance. While until then Jews who wanted to take part in these societies usually had to convert to Christianity, a definite change took place after 1848, when many former restrictions were lifted. Jews were especially successful in the employment of these opportunities for advancement through education. It is this trend which allowed Kafka Zweig, and Benjamin to study at the university, and made the idea of Benjamin receiving a university position tenable.  Jews had become intellectual leaders in the German-speaking world.

attachments.name: Jewish Soldiers in the Austro-Hungarian Army (English)

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: German-speaking Jews in the NLI Archives
children.data: Being integrated into German-speaking society, Jews such as Zweig and Benjamin saw themselves as part of European society, and conceived Jewish identity as a universal phenomenon which lived in harmony with their Europeanism. With the rise of the Nazis to power their world fell apart. Many such Jewish intellectuals including Zweig, Benjamin, the famous poet Elsa Lasker-Schüler , the poet and writer Albert Ehrenstein, and many more, sent their archives to the National Library in Palestine in order to save what they could of their life's achievements and records.

parent.name: Zweig, Benjamin, Kafka: Comets in the Sky of German Culture

children.name: Stefan Zweig (1881 – 1942)
children.data: The Austrian Jewish author Stefan Zweig was undoubtedly one of the great intellectuals of the 20th century. His novels, novellas, and historical biographies were best sellers, and were translated into more than fifty languages. He was extremely popular in Europe as well as in the United States and South America, and remains so today in Continental Europe. As a pacifist and a humanist who conceived the idea of a united Europe, an idea which was completely surreal at the time, Zweig was ahead of his time.

attachments.name: Austrian Coin In Memoriam Stefan Zweig.jpg

parent.name: German-speaking Jews in the NLI Archives

children.name: Zweig's Papers at the NLI
children.data: Zweig was not attracted to the National Jewish movement led by his close patron Herzl. Yet in the crucial hour, upon dismantling his house in Salzburg in 1933, Zweig chose to send his papers to the Library of the Jewish State in formation, which was located in Jerusalem and became The National Library of Israel.

children.name: First Steps as a Writer – Zweig and Herzl
children.data: In his student years Zweig wrote poetry as well as short texts and stories. Some of these were published in the leading newspaper of Vienna, the Neue Freie Presse. The literary editor of this paper was none other than Theodor Herzl, the leading figure in the National Jewish movement. Herzl became a mentor of the young Zweig, for whom publication in this prestigious newspaper was conceived as a literary knighthood, especially for a beginning writer.

attachments.name: Herzl's vision for a Jewish State, Altneuland.jpg
attachments.location: 8C71E338-7233-5876-B3D8-8B072725E49F\Herzl's vision for a Jewish State, Altneuland.jpg

children.name: :_: Theodore Herzl (1860 – 1904)
children.data:
Theodore (Binyamin Zeev) Herzl was a Jewish journalist from Austro-Hungaria who is considered as the father of the political Zionistic movement.

While serving as a correspondent of the Viennese paper, the Neue Freie Presse in Paris, Herzl witnessed the Dreyfus trial in which a Jewish army officer was unjustly accused of treason. Herzl was horrified upon seeing the mobs in Paris shouting: "Death to the Jews!" This, as well as many other anti-Semitic manifestations, brought him to the conclusion that the Jews must have a state of their own. In 1896

He published the revolutionary book, Der Judenstaat,  and from then on worked relentlessly to promote the idea of a Jewish National State.  Herzl died in 1904 and did not live to see his vision come true.

attachments.name: Herzl, First Zionist Congress at Basel, 1897.jpg

parent.name: First Steps as a Writer – Zweig and Herzl

children.name: Zweig's Letter To Martin Buber – on Judaism and Zionism

attachments.name: Zweig's Letter to Martin Buber,  24.1.1917, p.1.tif

children.name: :_: Martin Buber (1878-1965)
children.data:
Martin Buber was a philosopher, known first and foremost for his book  Ich und Du. In his book Buber promotes the personal and intimate dialogue between people (I-You), and rejects the alien impersonal dialogue (I-It). 

Buber was born to an observant Jewish family, yet chose to study philosophy. In 1930 he became an honorary Professor at Frankfurt am-Main, from which he resigned immediately after Hitler's rise to power.

In 1938 Buber immigrated to Israel and was appointed Professor at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Although an avid Zionist, Buber endorsed Humanistic Zionism which differed significantly from that of Herzl. Buber fought for Arab rights in Palestine, and supported the establishment of an Arab-Jewish State.

parent.name: Zweig's Letter To Martin Buber – on Judaism and Zionism

children.name: :1: Zweig and Judaism
children.data: Although born to Jewish parents, religion did not play a central role in his education.  When interviewed on this question Zweig said: "My mother and father were Jewish only through accident of birth". Zweig believed in universalism internationalism and in Europeanism and adopted Judaism in as far as it supported these ideas. Yet he did not renounce his Jewish faith and wrote repeatedly on Jews and Jewish themes, as in his story Buchmendel, and his Jewish identity clearly played a significant role in his life: “I have been vitally interested in Jewish problems all my life,” he wrote, “vitally aware of the Jewish blood that is in me ever since I have been conscious of it."

attachments.name: Zweig's Letter to Martin Buber,  24.1.1917, p.2.tif

parent.name: Zweig's Letter To Martin Buber – on Judaism and Zionism

children.name: :2: Zweig and the Zionist Movement
children.data:
Zweig rejected totally, however, the Zionist movement which strove to create a national home for all the Jews in their historical homeland. Zweig believed that being a Jew allows him to conduct his life according to humanistic values, and refused to join the "fanatical nationalistic movements".

In his letter to the famous Jewish philosopher Martin Buber, written in 24.1.1917 in the midst of WWI, Zweig expounds on his attitude towards Judaism and Zionism. Among other things Zweig mentions also the "fanatic and nationalistic views" of Kafka's close friend, Max Brod.

attachments.name: Zweig's Letter to Martin Buber,  24.1.1917, p.3.tif
Balfour Declaration as published in The Times 9 November 1917.jpg
attachments.location: BCD6A75F-82F3-6EDC-1024-7F03831F6CA0\Balfour Declaration as published in The Times 9 November 1917.jpg

parent.name: Zweig's Letter To Martin Buber – on Judaism and Zionism

children.name: :3: The Letter to Buber
children.data:
[...] Regarding my feelings as a Jew,  I have never felt as free as now, in the days of nationalist delusion. I am divided from you and your supporters  by the fact that I have never wished that Judaism would become a nation again, thus reducing itself to competing with the present realities.  I love the Diaspora and stand behind it because of its idealism, as well as its human and universal call.

I do not wish for any union other  than in spirit, the only real factor we have in common, never in a language, in nation, in customs and habits - beautiful but dangerous syntheses.

I regard the present situation as the best for mankind: this being one entity without language, without bonds, without a homeland –united only through the aura of entity. Any closer and more tangible unification seems to me a diminution of this unparalleled situation. The only quality which we must reinforce is not to view this situation as humiliation, but rather to accept it with love and with full awareness, as I do. [...]

attachments.name: Zweig's Letter to Martin Buber,  24.1.1917, p.4.tif

parent.name: Zweig's Letter To Martin Buber – on Judaism and Zionism

children.name: The World of Yesterday
children.data:
Zweig's autobiography, The World of Yesterday, preserves not only the memories of Zweig's life, but the memories of the cultural era, from the end of the 19th century to the onset of WWII. Zweig describes his days as a young boy, his experiences as a student, and the support he received from Theodore Herzl as a young and promising writer. Zweig does not only glorify this era, but expressly points out its drawbacks.

The typescript in the NLI is the only existing copy which is intact and contains corrections which were made by his wife Lotte. The copy was donated to the NLI by the translator of Zweig to Spanish, Alfredo Cahn, who lives in Argentina.

children.name: Zweig's Suicide Letter
children.data:
Having escaped the horrors of the war in Europe, Zweig and his wife looked for a refuge in which they could resume their lives. Disappointed with London and New-York, they had hoped to make a fresh start in Brazil. However, being constantly on the run, the encounter with multitudes of Jewish refugees like him, and the feeling that his cultural world was lost, filled him with great despair. He could not find within himself the strength to begin a new life.

Zweig's suicide was criticized by many. But he was not the only one: two other Jewish intellectuals who were war refugees, the author Ernest Toller in New-York, and the philosopher Walter Benjamin in Portbou, had committed suicide before him.  

 

Zweig's suicide letter was found by local police officers. They called in a German-Jewish doctor to translate the letter for them. The doctor who had read the note asked to keep it, but was refused.  20 years later, he was able to purchase it from a retired police officer. In 1991 he donated it to the National Library of Israel.

 

The Letter

Declaration

Of my own will and in clear mind

Every day I learned to love this country more, and I would not have asked to rebuild my life in any other place after the world of my own language sank and was lost to me and my spiritual homeland, Europe, destroyed itself.

 

But to start everything anew after a man’s 60th year requires special powers, and my own power has been expended after years of wandering homeless. I thus prefer to end my life at the right time, upright, as a man for whom cultural work has always been his purest happiness and personal freedom – the most precious of possessions on this earth.

 

I send greetings to all of my friends: May they live to see the dawn after this long night. I, who am most impatient, go before them.

Stefan Zweig, Petropolis, 22.2.1942.

children.name: Stefan Zweig's Life (1881-1942)
children.data: Zweig studied philosophy at the University of Vienna and in 1904 earned a doctoral degree. In those student years Zweig published his first book of poetry, as well as various pieces in the most prestigious newspaper in Vienna, the Neue Freie Presse whose editor was Theodore Herzl, the leading figure in the Jewish National Movement. Having proven his talent, Zweig was exempted from working in the family business.

children.name: :1: The Young Zweig
children.data: Zweig was born in Vienna to a wealthy Jewish family. His father was a textile manufacturer, and his mother came from a Jewish banking family. Already in his teens Zweig sent poems and articles to literary journals and corresponded with important literary figures. He also started a collection of manuscripts which included manuscripts of Goethe and Beethoven. Later on this collection came to include a catalogue of Mozart's works written in Mozart's own hand!

attachments.name: Stefan Zweig, standing, with his brother Alfred in Vienna, circa 1900..jpg
attachments.location: BA6FB0F3-55FE-774C-A33D-9B4DAA6DE1E6\Stefan Zweig, standing, with his brother Alfred in Vienna, circa 1900..jpg

children.name: :2: University Days
children.data: Zweig studied philosophy at the University of Vienna and in 1904 earned a doctoral degree. In those student years Zweig published his first book of poetry, as well as various pieces in the most prestigious newspaper in Vienna, the Neue Freie Presse whose editor was Theodore Herzl, the leading figure in the Jewish National Movement. Having proven his talent, Zweig was exempted from working in the family business.

attachments.name: Zweig's First Book of Poems, Silberne Saiten, (Strings of Silver) 1901.jpg
attachments.location: 3F6B26DA-4807-F910-03B7-2B37BAACCF97\Zweig's First Book of Poems, Silberne Saiten, (Strings of Silver) 1901.jpg

children.name: :3: The European Traveller
children.data: In the following decade Zweig moved constantly between Vienna, Berlin, Paris and Brussels. During this period he made the acquaintance of  famous poets, writers and artists such as Auguste Rodin, Rainer Maria Rilke, Romain Rolland, W.B. Yeats, Pirandello and many others. It was during this period that he started to write novellas and dramas which were warmly accepted by audiences.

attachments.name: Stefan Zweig's note in French to one of his Parisian Friends.jpg
attachments.location: F2317B51-A34D-3C3A-5C79-971679E39F03\Stefan Zweig's note in French to one of his Parisian Friends.jpg

attachments.name: Stefan Zweig on Rainer Maria Rilke.

children.name: :4: Stefan Zweig in WW I
children.data: When WWI broke out, Zweig, a patriotic Austrian, at first wrote pro-war articles. When the war began Zweig was conscripted and assigned to serve in the Austrian Archives of the Ministry of War. Having been exposed to the horrors of the war, Zweig underwent a significant change, and wrote a fervent anti-war drama called Jeremiah which won the acclaim of his friend, the famous author Thomas Mann. It was at that time, that Zweig  adopted an extreme pacifist position, as did his friend  the French novelist Romain Rolland. He then moved to Switzerland until the end of the war. Zweig remained a pacifist all his life and advocated the unification of Europe.

attachments.name: Poster of the Play Jeremiah by Stefan Zweig, The Ohel Theatre, Palestine, 1929, by Aryeh El-Hanani..jpg
attachments.location: 50F6B590-8A6C-A11A-E704-EB7A6C61EF9A\Poster of the Play Jeremiah by Stefan Zweig, The Ohel Theatre, Palestine, 1929, by Aryeh El-Hanani..jpg

children.name: :5: The  Fertile Salzburg Period (1919-1933)
children.data: In 1920 Zweig married Friderike Maria von Winternitz (whom he divorced in 1938), and moved into a grand house in Salzburg. In the following years he wrote a series of novellas and biographical works, which were full of emotional tensions and situations of social and psychological crises on issues such as gambling, prostitution, adultery, and suicide.Zweig's works became extremely popular, and were criticized by some of his colleagues as "railway carriage reading". Among these novellas were Amok, Fear, Compulsion and Twenty-Four Hours in the Life of a Woman, while the biographical works included Marie-Antoinette, Joseph Fouché and Magellan.

attachments.name: Stefan zweig with Romain Rolland, Villeneuve, Switzerland, 1933.jpg
attachments.location: BF444223-70EA-6FA3-A859-2978BACB205C\Stefan zweig with Romain Rolland, Villeneuve, Switzerland, 1933.jpg

children.name: :6: The Rise of the Nazis to power
children.data: With the rise of Hitler to power in 1933 Zweig's books were condemned in Germany and later banned. Fascism was on the rise in Austria as well, and when in 1934 the police came to search Zweig's home, he left his house never to return again. It was at this time that he divorced his first wife and moved to London, writing later that at that time he sensed the heavy clouds which were hanging above. At this point, Zweig dispersed his papers and sold his manuscript collection.
children.chronologicalName: The Rise of the Nazis to power

children.name: :7: 1934 – 1939 - London
children.data: In 1939 Zweig married his secretary Lotte Altmann. During these years Zweig did not express himself prominently against the Nazis or in support of the persecuted Jews, and was criticized for it by major Jewish figures like Hannah Arendt. He seems to have wanted to carry one with his life in London without much interference. Yet, it was at this time, that his writing started to center upon tormented figures, both literary and historical, who are in perilous situations. It was at this time that he wrote the biographies of Mary Queen of Scots and Marie-Antoinette, the novel Beware of Pity, and the novella The Chess Story which bears autobiographical elements.

attachments.name: Stefan Zweig with Joseph Roth, Austrian-Jewish Novelist, Ostende, Belgium, 1936..jpg
attachments.location: 9EA7CA9F-D56A-8450-3B0E-311EE2186CA5\Stefan Zweig with Joseph Roth, Austrian-Jewish Novelist, Ostende, Belgium, 1936..jpg

children.name: :8: London – New-York - Petropolis
children.data: Zweig and his wife received British citizenship, but were unhappy. In the World of Yesterday, which Zweig wrote before his death, he describes the Jewish refugees in London, as "ghosts" looking for a country to receive them. In 1940 the Zweigs left for New-York only to discover that he was surrounded again by refugees which reminded him of the terrible events in Europe. Just a few months later the Zweigs, having taken a tour of South-America, left for Petropolis Brazil, not far from Rio de Janeiro, where they hoped to have a chance for a fresh start. Zweig even wrote a book: Brazil – The Land of the Future.

children.name: :9: Suicide Letter
children.data: On February 22ed 1942 Stefan Zweig and his wife Lotte, having taken an overdose of barbituates, were found dead in their apartment in Petropolis. She was wearing her Kimono, he, wearing his shirt and tie. The previous evening Zweig had played chess with his neighbor, had gone home and written a letter of farewell, explaining his decision to leave the world.

children.name: :10: The House in Petropolis
children.data: The Zweigs' house in Brazil was later turned into a museum and is now known as Casa Stefan Zweig.

children.name: Walter Benjamin (1892-1940)
children.data: Walter Benjamin is widely known as a literary critic, translator, essayist, philosopher, intellectual and the great urban wanderer of the twentieth century. For many, Benjamin’s life and death, writings and philosophy, epitomize the twentieth century and the many changes it heralded, from the rise of popular culture, the advent of photography and the emergence of the urban realm as the primary arena of human experience, to the tension between myth and reality, eternity and apocalypse.

parent.name: German-speaking Jews in the NLI Archives

attachments.name: Walter Benjamin’s library card, Bibliothèque Nationale,  Paris, 1940.png
attachments.location: 063191BF-282F-35D3-AD28-70F721D9DD0C\Walter Benjamin’s library card, Bibliothèque Nationale,  Paris, 1940.png

children.name: :1: Youth
children.data: Walter Benjamin was born to a prosperous Jewish family in Berlin on July 15, 1892. He received a private education at home until the age of ten, after which he finished high school and studied philosophy at the Humboldt University of Berlin. As WWI broke out, Benjamin was beginning to translate the poetry of Charles Baudelaire. In 1915, at the age of 23, Benjamin moved to Munich where he met Gershom Scholem, the future founder of modern Kabbalah research, with whom he forged a close friendship that would last for many years. In Munich, Benjamin also met the poet Rainer Maria Rilke and authored a paper on the poet Hölderlin.

children.name: :2: The Hardships of a Young Critic, Translator and Philosopher
children.data: Having managed to avoid being drafted into the German army by feigning lower back pain, Benjamin moved to Bern in Switzerland in 1917. There, in 1919, he received his doctorate on "The Concept of Art Criticism in German Romanticism", summa cum laude. However, failing to find his niche in the academic world, Benjamin struggled to make a living. By this time he was married to Dora Pollack and father to a son named Stefan Raphael. Benjamin wrote an essay entitled: "A Critique of Violence", published a translation of Baudelaire and continued to write and research, but the family’s financial situation deteriorated as a result of the crisis in the Weimar Republic.

attachments.name: Bejamin's dissertation, The Concept of Art Criticism in German Romanticism.jpg
attachments.location: A2C82F85-76FE-26E0-C04C-6C8F88F64926\Bejamin's dissertation, The Concept of Art Criticism in German Romanticism.jpg

children.chronologicalName: The Hardships of a Young Critic, Translator and Philosopher

children.name: :3: Benjamin, Scholem, and Zionism
children.data: In 1923 Benjamin’s good friend Gerschom Scholem, influenced by Martin Buber, decided to immigrate to Palestine (Eretz Yisrael). Scholem invited Benjamin to join him, later even trying to entice him with a lectureship at the Hebrew University, but to no avail. Benjamin had never been drawn to Zionism, seeing Judaism, like Zweig, as a spiritual-cultural force in Europe: "My life experience led me to this insight: the Jews represent an elite in the ranks of the spiritually active ... For Judaism is to me in no sense an end in itself, but the most distinguished bearer and representative of the spiritual."

children.name: :4: A European Intellectual in the 1920's
children.data: Benjamin continued writing in German and gradually won himself recognition in the intellectual community. A study he wrote on a novel by Goethe, a book on the origin of German tragedy and his ongoing research activities were supposed to pave the way to tenure at a German University, but this was not to be. In the 1920's Benjamin translated part of Proust’s À la recherche du temps perdu, wrote for the newspapers and lived for a while in Paris. There in the bustling modern French capital, he began his great work on Parisian life in the 19th century.

attachments.name: The Origin of German Tragic Drama, Walter Benjamin.jpg
attachments.location: 2D87E24D-E771-A01F-7AC8-6424F12BDB73\The Origin of German Tragic Drama, Walter Benjamin.jpg

children.name: :5: 1929 -1940: Berlin- Ibiza –Nice- Paris Berlin
children.data: Momentous political changes were occurring in Germany and all over Europe.  With Hitler’s rise to power, Benjamin wandered to Ibiza in Spain and then Nice, France. After the burning of the Reichstag in 1933 he settled in Paris and mixed with a group of exiled German intellectuals: Hannah Arendt, Kurt Weill, Herman Hesse and others. Benjamin, who struggled to earn a living as an exile in Paris, immersed himself in his work.  He wrote about Baudelaire, spending long days in the libraries and wandering the streets of Paris by night. He continued working on his 19th century Paris piece and wrote “On the Concept of History”.

attachments.name: Walter Benjamin - Plaque commémorative 10 rue Dombasle, 75015 Paris.jpg
attachments.location: 97F1239D-149E-FD6A-7BF3-6C48E4B27E43\Walter Benjamin - Plaque commémorative 10 rue Dombasle, 75015 Paris.jpg

children.name: Letter by Walter Benjamin to Gershom Scholem, Berlin 28 February 1933
children.data: In this letter, apparently the last one written by Benjamin to Scholem in Germany, Benjamin has only begun to comprehend the severity of the changes in his homeland. Though he refers to the worsening situation in Germany after the Nazi's takeover in January 1933 as one of his reasons for leaving, he is also occupied with the growing complications involving the publication of his works. Towards the end, he expresses his opinion that Kafka's works are misinterpreted by some of their contemporaries.

attachments.name: Letter by Walter Benjamin to Gershom Scholem, Berlin 28.2.1933, p.1.jpeg.jpg
attachments.location: C588E3AE-91EB-2A99-50B8-6520308382D6\Letter by Walter Benjamin to Gershom Scholem, Berlin 28.2.1933, p.1.jpeg.jpg

attachments.name: Letter by Walter Benjamin to Gershom Scholem, 28.2.1933, p.2.jpg
attachments.location: C588E3AE-91EB-2A99-50B8-6520308382D6\Letter by Walter Benjamin to Gershom Scholem, 28.2.1933, p.2.jpg

children.name: :6: Fleeing from the Nazis
children.data: In 1938 German Jews were stripped of their citizenship and Benjamin became a stateless exile. He was arrested and incarcerated for three months. Leaving Paris on June 13th, just a day before the Wehrmacht entered Paris with an order to arrest him at his flat, Benjamin fled with his sister south, to Lourdes.  His hope was to reach the USA, for which he had managed to secure a visa through his friend Max Horkheimer. Having reached the Pyrenees, he crossed the border into Spain with a group of refugees and the assistance of a guide.

attachments.name: Deutsches Historisches Museum Berlin – Diversity Destroyed. Berlin 1933 – 1938

children.name: :7: Despair and Suicide
children.data: Having barely survived the arduous trail across the Pyrenees, he learnt, upon arriving at Portbou in Catalonia, that the Franco regime was not willing to accept any more refugees. Faced with the prospect of being deported to France and arrested by the Nazis, an ailing, exhausted, lost and desperate Benjamin took an overdose of morphine pills. He died on 25 September 1940, at the age of 48. Benjamin's brother Georg was killed at the Mathausen concentration camp in 1942. The tragedy was enhanced by the fact that in fact the rest of the group was later allowed to continue to Lisbon, and arrived there on September 30th.

children.name: Philosopher and Critic of Modern Intellectual Trends
children.data:
Benjamin’s philosophy drew upon several sources:  aesthetics, Marxist theory, the philosophy of Theodore Adorno and the Frankfurt School, and the influence of Jewish mysticism as encountered through the works of Gershom Scholem. Today, Walter Benjamin is perceived as a seminal critic of twentieth century western intellectual trends, someone who viewed the proletariat as the central force on the historical and cultural stage, understood the significance of the city in modernist perceptions and the new human experience, and dealt intensively with the importance of translation as a cultural act.

 

Photo of the Frankfurt School:  Horkheimer (front left),  Adorno (front right) and Habermas (background, right).

attachments.name: Walter Benjamin and Bertolt Brecht playing Chess.jpg
attachments.location: 0D46F88A-0E6D-309A-FCEF-E7D11C0DEC02\Walter Benjamin and Bertolt Brecht playing Chess.jpg

attachments.name: Members of the Frankfurt School,  1964 by J. Shapiro, Heidelberg.png
attachments.location: 0D46F88A-0E6D-309A-FCEF-E7D11C0DEC02\Members of the Frankfurt School,  1964 by J. Shapiro, Heidelberg.png

children.name: Benjamin's Commemorative Essay on Franz Kafka , 1934
children.data: This is Benjamin's personal copy of his essay commemorating Franz Kafka on the occasion of the tenth year after his death, written in exile in 1934. Benjamin was one of the first who dealt intensively with Kafka's work and its Jewish contexts. In this text he also discusses exhaustively a number of famous works by Kafka, among them The Trial. Like others, this typescript with Benjamin's own handwritten corrections, was sent by him to Scholem, who had already been living in Jerusalem for over a decade.

attachments.name: Benjamin's commemorative essay on Franz Kafka.jpg

parent.name: Philosopher and Critic of Modern Intellectual Trends

children.name: Harbinger of the 21st Century
children.data: Walter Benjamin paid much heed to photography seeing it as a new medium in that it had the power to redefine the distance between people, and between people and objects. Questions of proximity and distance, integration and alienation, transfer of concepts and perceptions between people and cultures, and impact of the subjective historical perspective on literary creativity and on the world in general, and no less so the tension between eternity and apocalypse, refined society versus primal forces of violence and destruction – all these make Walter Benjamin an exceedingly relevant thinker at the beginning of the 21st century.

attachments.location: 95934A56-2137-1032-C7F4-2BD7F29A375E\Source and Copy relations, The Mona Lisa.jpg

attachments.name: Walter Benjamin's The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction_XV.m4v

children.name: Benjamin's Archive at the NLI
children.data: When Benjamin felt the ground beginning to tremble under his feet he started thinking of the possibility of immigrating to Palestine, as did many other German-Jews at the time. Although he never reached Palestine, he had been sending material to his close friend Gershom Scholem, who was at first head of The Judaica department at the National Library and since 1925 a University professor at the Hebrew University. In fact, Benjamin wrote to Scholem that these materials are all part of the Beniaminia archive which he was slowly building. Benjamin, like Zweig, understood that if he were to perish, the NLI is the only real safe haven for his intellectual work when all else is lost.

attachments.name: The Manuscript of Walter Benjamin's Trauerspielbuch, 1925 .png
attachments.location: FF8523E3-155F-6F3D-37FB-5E17940C6DAF\The Manuscript of Walter Benjamin's Trauerspielbuch, 1925 .png

attachments.name: Benjamin's handwritten notebook, with parchment cover, at the National Library.jpg
attachments.location: FF8523E3-155F-6F3D-37FB-5E17940C6DAF\Benjamin's handwritten notebook, with parchment cover, at the National Library.jpg

children.name: Letter to Gershom Scholem, Paris, 20 March 1933
children.data: In this letter Benjamin mentions to Scholem his intention of staying in Ibiza for a while, a plan which will materialize somewhat later.  He also informs him of a new manuscript he will soon be sending. Benjamin notes that "this text is especially meant to adorn your archive", probably because it refers to Hebrew as well. The typescript which bears the title Über die Sprache überhaupt und über die Sprache des Menschen, also hebräisch (About language as such, and about the language of people, as well as about Hebrew) was indeed sent and is found in the Walter Benjamin archives.

attachments.location: ECB2D7AF-DF48-0A65-D929-5639449F580C\Letter by Walter Benjamin to Gershom Scholem, Paris, 20 March 1933, p.1 (2).jpg
