attachments.location: ECB2D7AF-DF48-0A65-D929-5639449F580C\Letter by Walter Benjamin to Gershom Scholem, Paris, 20 March 1933, p.2.jpg

children.name: Franz Kafka (1883 – 1924)
children.data:
Franz Kafka is one of the most prominent authors writing in German during the 20th century. Born in Prague in 1883, Kafka belonged to the intellectual milieu of Jews in Prague who identified themselves with the German culture and language. Together with Max Brod, Felix Weltsch, and Oskar Baum, Kafka was part of the "Close Prague Circle", a group of Jewish authors who met regularly and collaborated in their literary work.

Making his living as an insurance officer, Kafka had low esteem for his work. It was only after his death that his works were published, due to the efforts of his good friend Max Brod and earned him a special place in the "Hall of Fame" of classic modern German literature.

parent.name: German-speaking Jews in the NLI Archives

children.name: Kafka and Judaism
children.data: Although from a Jewish family, Kafka's Jewish education was minimal and amounted to a few visits a year at the Synagogue. Yet, in 1911, having been enchanted by a Yiddish theatre performance, he took up the study of Yiddish language and literature; as a consequence of this his interest in Judaism was aroused. During the early 1920's in Prague Kafka started studying modern Hebrew. Under the influence of his last lover, Dora Diamant, who came from an Orthodox Jewish family, Kafka even showed interest in the Talmud! It was during that time, when they were living in Berlin, that Kafka took classes in Judaism.

children.name: :1: Kafka's Hebrew Booklet
children.data:
Beginning in 1917, Kafka spent time learning Hebrew, first by himself, and later with various teachers. This is one out of five booklets filled with vocabulary by Kafka and the only one kept at the National Library of Israel.

In his last years he studied with Pu'ah Ben Tovim, a young student from Jerusalem, who came recommended by his good friend S.H. Bergmann, and was staying as a student in Bergmann's mother home in Prague. Kafka and Ben-Tovim  were reading the Hebrew novel Breakdown and Bereavement by Y.H. Brenner, and there are testimonies that he was able to speak and even to write simple letters in Hebrew.

Some of the words included in this booklet very much remind us of the imaginary world of the author: passion, cockroach, escape, illusion etc.

children.name: :2: Kafka and Zionism
children.data: Although initially Kafka viewed himself as a Socialist and rejected the Zionist views of his childhood friend S.H. Bergmann, he deliberated several times, with four of his women partners to immigrate to Palestine! A short while before his death he wrote to Bergmann, who had been in Palestine since 1920, of his plan to visit. The plan never materialized as Kafka's illness deteriorated rapidly.

attachments.name: 'Kafka's lifelong dream was to make aliyah'

children.name: :3: Hosting Kafka at Bergmann's Home
children.data:
In summer 1923 Kafka had written to Bergmann about his plan to visit Palestine. In a letter dated August 1923 Bergmann wrote  to his wife Else the following:

"Regarding Kafka: I would of course be very glad to have him here, but I beg you not to take this burden upon yourself and upon our house. The room in the cellar is taken up by Lea (the maid), and it is doubtful whether this room is suited for living, especially when it comes to Franz. Even Lea had not wanted this room…As long as mother is here, we do not have a spare room. Even if she leaves – who knows when that will happen – there will still be the problem of attending to Franz. It is one thing to help him as much as possible when he is living abroad, but it's another, when you invite him to our home and take upon yourself the responsibility and the care. This will end up at the expense of the children! … You know that I love Franz very much, and would like him to stay with me, but I ask you to make no commitments or to build up (his) hopes."

children.name: Shmuel Hugo Bergmann (1883-1975)
children.data: S.H. Bergmann was a philosopher and intellectual. Bergmann and Kafka grew up together in Prague. Although they attended the same schools and were close friends, Bergmann was an avid Zionist and his Jewish origins were central to his self- identity. He immigrated to Palestine in 1920, and was appointed as Head of the National Library, an office he held until 1935. Bergmann was appointed also as Professor of Philosophy at the Hebrew University and served as the University Rector. Together with Martin Buber, Gershom Scholem, and others, Bergmann was a member of Brit Shalom, "Covenant of Peace", which supported the Coexistence of Jews and Arabs in one state.

attachments.name: Bergman and the Czech Presidant Masaryk on their Way to Visit the National Library, Jerusalem, 1927.jpg
attachments.location: F8764905-77D6-2F1F-C4A6-0376797AED4A\Bergman and the Czech Presidant Masaryk on their Way to Visit the National Library, Jerusalem, 1927.jpg

attachments.name: Jaroslav Róna's bronze statue of Franz Kafka in Prague.jpg
attachments.location: BECC5ABA-AB23-EA10-9DD6-17B72E29AE48\Jaroslav Róna's bronze statue of Franz Kafka in Prague.jpg

children.name: :1: Childhood and Youth
children.data:
Franz Kafka was born in 1883, to a German-speaking Jewish family. He was the first of six children, though only he and his three sisters reached adulthood. His father, who ran a retail business, was a domineering uneducated man, while his mother was a quiet, shy, well-educated woman.  Kafka suffered from his father's authoritarian attitude; this relationship left a dominant mark on his psyche, as is evident from the Letter to His Father (early 1920's).

Kafka, who was an excellent student, studied at a German elementary school, and later in a classic German Gymnasium where High German was taught. Although he spoke Czech, he cultivated his German and identified with the German culture.

attachments.name: Kafka, 10 Years Old, With His Sisters.jpg

children.name: :2: University Days,
children.data: Like many middle-class Jews in Prague, Kafka chose to continue his higher education at the German Charles Ferdinand University, where he at first studied chemistry and later law. It was during this period that he made the acquaintance of  Felix Weltsch, Oskar Baum, Franz Werfel, and Max Brod; Kafka, Weltsch and Brod would later call themselves  Der enge Prager Kreis ("The Close Prague Circle").

attachments.name: Franz Kafka and Max Brod on the Beach.jpg
attachments.location: B9A5DA7A-D132-ACC5-C1EB-F21A3A65455A\Franz Kafka and Max Brod on the Beach.jpg

attachments.name: Kafka with his sister Ottilie near their Parents house in Prague.jpg
attachments.location: B9A5DA7A-D132-ACC5-C1EB-F21A3A65455A\Kafka with his sister Ottilie near their Parents house in Prague.jpg

children.name: :3: Kafka and Friends  in Vienna, 1913
children.data:
Kafka and Friends at the pleasure ground "Prater" in Vienna, 1913

In 1913, Franz Kafka attended two large congresses in Vienna: a professional congress of insurance officers and the 11th Zionist Congress, where he met friends: the expressionistic authors Albert Ehrenstein and Otto Pick, as well as Lise Weltsch, Felix Weltsch's cousin, who was from Prague as well. As seen on the photograph, the friends did not only attend sessions of the Zionist Congress, but also spent some leisure time together. This photograph, survived in two personal archives at the National Library of Israel: in Albert Ehrenstei's archives  and among Lise Weltsch's papers.

attachments.name: Kafka and Friends at the pleasure ground Prater in Vienna, 1913.jpg
attachments.location: A420860D-74E0-837F-B44D-486B85BBE00F\Kafka and Friends at the pleasure ground Prater in Vienna, 1913.jpg

children.name: :4: Kafka's Private Life
children.data:
Kafka had many relationships with women. He had actually been betrothed to four of them, though none of these close relationships ever ended in marriage.

During WWI  Kafka received a draft notice.  At first he was exempted by his employers; later, in 1917, when he attempted to enlist, Kafka was diagnosed with Tuberculosis, from which he suffered increasingly until his painful death in 1924.

attachments.name: Dora Diamant, Kafka's Lover, 1923-1924 Until His Death.jpg
attachments.location: AA67C69C-E433-132A-305B-A0BB13C9B4A8\Dora Diamant, Kafka's Lover, 1923-1924 Until His Death.jpg

attachments.name: Milena Jesenská, Kafkas Passionate Correspondent and Unfulfilled Love, 1919-1923.jpg
attachments.location: AA67C69C-E433-132A-305B-A0BB13C9B4A8\Milena Jesenská, Kafkas Passionate Correspondent and Unfulfilled Love, 1919-1923.jpg

children.name: :5: Letter to Lise Weltsch, 1914
children.data: In spring 1914, Franz Kafka was about to go to Berlin in order to be betrothed to his first fiancée, Felice Bauer (whom he never married). In this letter Kafka invites Lise Weltsch, the young lady who was photographed with him and other friends from Vienna, to meet him and his fiancée in Berlin. Kafka expresses his delight at leaving his parents' home in Prague where he was residing then, and coming to spend some time in Berlin.

children.name: :6: The Bread Job and the Calling
children.data: After graduating in 1906 and completing his year of training, Kafka started to work as an insurance officer.  Kafka called this his Brotberuf or "Bread Job", and constantly bemoaned the fact that he did not have enough time for his real passion: writing. Despite this he wrote almost incessantly, writing stories, novels and letters. Yet, he was extremely critical regarding his works; as a result, many of his texts remained unfinished. Thus, his three famous novels, The Castle, The Trial, The Missing Man, as well as a number of stories were found unfinished by his close friend, the writer Max Brod. One of the most famous stories is The Metamorphosis, relating the story of the miserable Gregor Samsa who woke up one morning finding himself transformed into a huge insect.
children.chronologicalName: The Bread Job and the Calling

children.name: :7: Death
children.data: Kafka died from tuberculosis at the age of 41; at that time the few texts he had published were known only among his friends and admirers from his close avant-garde literary circle. Fame was to come soon after his death when his best friend, Max Brod, refused to carry out Kafka's will in which he instructed him to burn all his writings. Max Brod chose to complete the many unfinished manuscripts and to publish them. Success and fame came soon afterwards!

children.name: Elimelech Basch's Diary
children.data:
Elimelech Basch was a member of the Jewish community of Tiachiv in eastern Hungary (today western Ukraine), invaded by the Nazis in March 1944. Between the years 1942-1944 Basch kept a diary, written in fine Hebrew, which describes the situation of the Jewish community there. During this period the Jews suffered from the oppressive Hungarian and Nazi regimes and moved between despair and hope.

During the Jewish festival of Shavuot, May 1944, the Jews of Tiachiv were all deported to Auschwitz.  Of the Basch family - parents and their eight children – only one survived.

 

Photograph: The Basch family at the beginning of the 1930's.  

Highlighted is the only surviving member of the family, Mrs. Perhiya Senderovich (formerly Bluma Blanka Basch), who now lives in Israel.

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: :_: The Hebrew Language
children.data:
The Hebrew language is the ancient language which was spoken and written by the people of Israel already in the beginning of the first millennium. It is the language of the Old Testament and other scriptures of the Jewish people. Although from the second temple period onwards Jews started speaking other languages as well (Aramaic, Greek and later other European vernacular languages), it remained the language of the Scriptures and prayer, and was called "The Holy Tongue".

Jews continued to learn, to read and write Hebrew throughout the last two millennia although it was not their spoken language, since it was their ancient holy language.

 

Photographs: The Worms Mahzor (festival prayerbook), Germany, 13th century, NLI. The prayerbook was used by the Worms community until the synagogue's destruction on Kristallnacht, November 1938. It was rescued by the city archivist who hid it in the cathedral, and was transferred in 1957 to the NLI.

children.name: A National Language
children.data:
During the second half of the 19th century, when National movements in Europe arose, the Jewish Zionist movement was one of them. The revival of the ancient Hebrew language was one of the important goals of the Zionist movement. This explains why Elimelech Bash chose to write his diary in Hebrew.

Today, Hebrew is the official language of Israel and is the main spoken language in the country.

 

Photograph: Hatikva, Hymn of the state of Israel, written by Naphtali Herz Imber, autograph, 1907-8, The National Library of Israel.

attachments.name: Ha Tikva - The Israeli Anthem, an autograph by N.H. Imber.jpg
attachments.location: F8A8EC39-68D8-ECCF-6F51-12C17F60061D\Ha Tikva - The Israeli Anthem, an autograph by N.H. Imber.jpg

children.name: :1: The Jewish Community of Tiachiv
children.data: The last census before the German occupation, held in January 1941, reported 2,150 Jewish residents in Tiachiv. They were 20% of the total population of the town.  Many of the Jews were merchants; others were craftsmen and agricultural workers and farmers.  The Jewish community was, as were most communities in Eastern Europe, a religious observant Orthodox community.

attachments.name: Rare Color Footage Depicting Jewish Life in the Shtetl Before the Holocaust
Map of Jewish communities before the Holocaust, within the borders of today's Ukraine.jpg
attachments.location: CB8A2990-88AF-CFC3-80F0-4AAB42999E55\Map of Jewish communities before the Holocaust, within the borders of today's Ukraine.jpg

children.name: :2: Dark Times
children.data:
In March 1939 Tiachiv came under Hungarian sovereignty and the Jews suffered from oppressive legislation. The synagogue was sacked, and beatings and harassment became part of the Jews' everyday life.

The German army conquered Hungary on the 19.3.1944.  A ghetto was established in April, and about 10,000 Jews from the region were deported into the ghetto. Each apartment contained 10-15 persons, no food was supplied and the population began to starve. 

Those who tried to escape were turned over to the Hungarian police who cooperated with the Nazis.The Jews of the Tiachiv ghetto were deported to the extermination camp in Auschwitz between the 22nd-26th of May, 1944.

children.name: :_: The Holocaust
children.data:
One of the most distinct characteristics of the Nazi regime was its ideology of the  supremacy of the Aryan race and its detestation of the Jews and other groups. In 1942, in the Wannsee conference, the Nazis decided to implement a plan called the “Final Solution of the Jewish Question”. After that the Jews of Europe were systematically murdered in the extermination camps as part of the Final Solution. In some of the camps permanent gas chambers were erected.

By 1945 6,000,000 Jews, the majority of the Jews in Europe, were dead.

For more on the Holocaust follow the link to Yad Vashem's website.

children.name: :3: The family's Last Days
children.data:
Elimelech Basch described in his diary his family's last days.  Until the last moment, after the Germans had already entered the town, the family debated what to do:

"I argued with my wife that she shouldn't clean and paint for (the holiday of) Passover, but she continued her work as usual saying that as long as we live we should hope for the good and God will choose to do as he sees fit. My son Isaac, seeing my great anxiety, said that I should buy a gun and shoot all the members of our family".

…" I watched my children play and wept, who knows what will happen to them?"

attachments.name: The Basch Diary, The Last Days.jpg

children.name: :4: The Deportation to the Death Camps
children.data:
Elimelech Basch, his wife Miriam and their eight children were deported to Auschwitz during the 22nd-26th of May, 1944. Elimelech (46), Miriam (40), Isac (18), Mordechai (14), Hershl (12), Yisrael (10), Moshe (8), Shlomo (6) and little Esther, aged 4, were all murdered in the death camp.   Bluma (Perhiya), the eldest daughter, aged about 20 at the time, was the only one who survived the hell of Auschwitz.  Until this day she is not willing to tell what happened to her in Auschwitz during the war, not even to her closest family.

Movie: The May 1944 deportations, on which the Basch family was sent to the death camps.

The photographs in this album were taken on May-June 1944 by two SS men whose task was to take ID photos and fingerprints from the inmates of the Camp.

attachments.name: The Auschwitz Album- Visual Evidence of the Process Leading to the Mass Murder at Auschwitz-Birkenau

children.chronologicalName: The Deportation to the Death Camps

children.name: :5: Surviving Daughter in Israel
children.data:
Elimelech Basch's eldest daughter, Bluma (Perhiya), was the only one of the Basch family who survived.  Bluma emigrated to Israel, changed her name to Perhiya and built a new family.  Perhiya has three children, many grandchildren and a newborn great granddaughter.  She is now 87 years old. She is still an active volounteer in her hometown Lydda (Lod).  

 

Photograph: In the center Perhiya receiving a token of gratitude from the city of Lydda for her long years as a volunteer.

 

Photograph: Perhiya's testimony, given in January 1956, regarding the murder of her family.  The testimony was given to the Yad Vashem museum for the memory of the Holocaust in Jerusalem, Israel.

children.name: :6: The Diary at The National Library of Israel
children.data: After the war Elimelech Basch's brother Jacob, who survived the Holocaust, came back and found the diary. He later gave it to Basch's only remaining daughter - Perhiya -  who lives in Israel. She, in turn, decided to donate the diary for safekeeping to the National library of Israel for the generations to come.
children.chronologicalName: The Diary at The National Library of Israel

children.name: Maps of The Holy Land in the Eran Laor collection
children.data:
From ancient times the Holy Land has been the focus of great attraction for both Jews and Christians and Muslims. Throughout the ages Jews and Christians have made pilgrimages to the Holy Land, envisaged scenes and stories from the Scriptures, and dreamt of it from afar. Many of them left behind them descriptions and studies of the Holy Land accompanied by views and drawings.

The Eran Laor map collection in the National Library of Israel contains about 1500 maps of Jerusalem and of the Holy Land from the beginning of print up to our days.

attachments.name: Civitas Hierusalem, Bertelli, Donato,  Venice, 16th century [156- ].jpg
Hierusalem, Du Perac,  Stefano . Roma, c.1570.jpg

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land
children.data: Depictions of the Holy Land appeared mostly in Bibles, in travel books, and in histories and geographies. With the invention of the printing press it became worthwhile to produce large and detailed drawings which were then printed in several editions. These drawings are often called maps, although they were really often rather naïve and romantic impressions. Diachronic in nature, they often record events from the past and the future on one map. Favored scenes are the land as promised to Abraham, or Jerusalem in the time of Jesus. The readers were thus introduced to this unique site where momentous events occurred and are yet to occur in the future.

attachments.name: Palestinae sive totius Terrae Promissionis, Ortelius,  Stella and van Diest, 1575.jpg
attachments.location: AE0BA84A-88FB-0EC6-25D5-BDD81F99F748\Palestinae sive totius Terrae Promissionis, Ortelius,  Stella and van Diest, 1575.jpg

parent.name: Maps of The Holy Land in the Eran Laor collection

children.name: Adrichom's Map of Jerusalem
children.data: Christian van Adrichom was a Catholic priest and theologian. A native of Delft, he fled to Cologne  in the wake of the religious turmoil of the Reformation. His map of Jerusalem is part of his book, published in 1584, on the antiquities and history of the Holy Land and is based on the Bible, Josephus Flavius, and many other sources. Purporting to depict Jerusalem in the time of Jesus, it includes a variety of illustrations representing sundry historical periods. Adrichom's map was one of the most popular and influential maps of the period and was often copied.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Biblical Scenes in Adrichom's map
children.data: Biblical Scenes are represented widely in Adrichom's map:

children.name: :1: King David's palace
children.data: The palace of King David and above it Bathsheba, the future mother of King Solomon, bathing on the roof near the palace.

children.name: :2: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple
children.data: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple depicted in detail: The Temple Courtyard drawn according to Josephus' description, the Ark and the Cherubim, the High Priest, the Candelabrum and the Table of the Showbread, as well as the Sacrificial Altar in front of the Temple.
children.chronologicalName: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple

children.name: :3: The shrine of the idol Moloch
children.data: The Temple of the Ammonite idol Moloch that King Solomon built in the Valley of Gehena (I Kings: 11:7).  According to the Bible (I Kings 16:3; 21:6), the kings of Judah Ahaz and Manasseh took part in the Moloch ritual by passing their sons through the fire. At the bottom, the sawing of the tree where the Prophet Isaiah was hidden by the slaves of the wicked king Manasseh, and Isaiah's sepulcher are depicted.
children.chronologicalName: The shrine of the idol Moloch

children.name: :4: The Babylonian army camp
children.data: The camp of the Babylonian army besieging Jerusalem on the eve of the destruction of the First Temple.

children.name: The Via Dolorosa
children.data: The Via Dolorosa of Jesus, from his trial to his Crucifixion is depicted in detail in Adrichom's map.

children.name: :1: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace
children.data: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace where the Trial of Jesus takes place and Pilate declares: "Crucifige".
children.chronologicalName: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace

children.name: :2: The Via Dolorosa
children.data: The Via Dolorosa – Jesus is commanded to carry the Cross, he falls, and is then assisted by Simon of Cyrene.

children.name: :3: The Crucifixion
children.data: The Crucifixion of Jesus and the two thieves, the two Marys standing under the cross, Jesus being taken down from the Cross and buried, and the Resurrection.

children.name: Ortelius' Map
children.data:
This map was made by the famous publisher, Abraham Ortelius active in the Low Countries during the 16th century who, in an age of great geographical discoveries was the first to print a modern atlas. Although a "modern" cartographer at the time, Ortelius dedicated a special map to "The Life and Peregrination of the Patriarch Abraham to the Promised Land".  

The biblical passage (Genesis 12: 1-2) commanding Abraham to leave on the journey appears along the top frame of the map:  “Go from your country, your people and your father’s household to the land I will show you", while on the bottom appears Genesis 17:8: "The whole land of Canaan, where you now reside as a foreigner, I will give as an everlasting possession to you and your descendants after you ."

attachments.name: Ortelius Cartouch and top biblical passage.jpg

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems
children.data:
The most captivating feature in this map are the picture emblems which tell the story of Abraham:

Abraham's family led by Abraham and his father Terah, are commanded by God to leave Haran for the Promised Land (Genesis 11:31).

children.name: :1: The altar at Beth-El
children.data: After returning to Canaan from Egypt Abraham builds an altar in Beth-El where God appeared to him and promised to give the land to him and to his descendants. (Genesis 13:1-12)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :2: Abraham and Melchizedek
children.data: After defeating the rebellious kings in the Valley of Siddim Abraham (kneeling in his armour) is met by Melchizedek king of Shalem (the future Jerusalem) and priest to the Most High God, who offers him bread and wine and gives him a blessing. (Genesis 14:18-20)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :3: The Covenant of the Parts
children.data: Having promised Abraham as many descendants as the stars, God promises the land to Abraham through theCovenant of the Parts. On the right: God is standing behind Abraham, while Abraham's servant prepares the animals for sacrifice. On the left: the covenant is sealed by a burning torch, the divine fire consuming Abraham's sacrifice. (Genesis 15)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :4: Sarah gives Abraham her slave-girl
children.data: When Sarah despairs of having a child, she gives Abraham her slave-girl so that she may bear him a child. (Genesis 16)

attachments.name: Ortelius Sarah gives Abraham her slave-girl.jpg

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :5: The three angels
children.data: Abraham is visited by the three angels. While offering them a place to rest and water to wash  their feet, he is given the surprising tidings that he and Sarah will soon have a child. Sarah is seen in the background preparing the calf. (Genesis 18)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :6: Birth of Isaac
children.data: Sarah is giving birth to Isaac. The new-born baby is being held by the midwife while the maids assist Sarah. (Genesis 21:1-6).

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :7: Abraham banishes Hagar and Ishma'el
children.data: After Isaac is born, Abraham sends Hagar away with Ishma'el while the feast in honour of the newborn Isaac is taking place in the background. The protecting angel hovers above the scene. (Genesis 21:8-11)

attachments.name: Ortelius Banishment of Hagar and Ishma'el.jpg

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :8: The sacrifice of Isaac
children.data: The Sacrifice of Isaac: on the right Abraham prays asking God to annul this terrible decree, while on the left he is raising the knife when his gaze is guided by the angel towards the ram which he his commanded to offer in Isaac's stead.  (Genesis 22)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :9: Abraham's death
children.data: Abraham's Death: Abraham is being lowered into the grave in the Cave of the Makhpela to be buried beside Sarah. (Genesis 25)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: Journeys to Jerusalem
children.data: Christians throughout the ages were drawn to Jerusalem, captivated by its glorious past: it was the city into which according to Christian tradition Jesus made his Triumphal Entry, the stage upon which the events of the Great Week took place, and the place of his Crucifixion and Resurrection and the Ascension. It was also the city of David and Solomon and the setting of a multitude of biblical events. Although many pilgrims and scholars purported to depict "modern" Jerusalem, their maps often followed much earlier maps, and their main aim was to map out the Christian sites, usually ignoring the Muslim presence in the city.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: :1: Daumont's Map
children.data:
Jean François Daumont made this beautiful map of Jerusalem in 1780. However, it was actually copied from a map originally drawn almost 300 years beforehand, in 1486, following the pilgrimage of Bernhard of Breydenbach to Jerusalem in 1483.

Daumont marks Christian and Muslim monuments with a cross or crescent, but does not name the Muslim monuments. In fact, Daumont chooses to call the mosques on the Temple Mount by their Crusader name: "Templum Salomonis", preferring history to reality.

children.name: :2: Braun and Hogenberg's map
children.data:
This view of Jerusalem was one of three maps of the city included in the famous city atlas compiled by Braun and Hoghenberg, in 1575. The quotation from Ezek. 5:5 at the top of the map conveys the idea of Jerusalem as the center of the earth, while the citation from Pliny the Elder on the bottom left lauds "Jerusalem, the most famous of the cities in the Orient, Metropolis of Judaea".

The city is seen here from the perspective of pilgrims standing on the Mount of Olives, looking eastwards. Although the round shape of the city is schematic, there are various realistic elements such as the citadel in the background, the bridges over the Kidron valley and the blocked doorway to the church of the Holy Sepulcher.

attachments.name: Jerusalem, Hogenberg,  Braun and Jansson, Amsterdam, 1657.jpg

children.name: :3: Dapper's map
children.data:
Dapper (1635-1689), who never travelled outside Holland, collected a lot of information about the Holy Land and many other countries. His realistic map (1677) relied on the map made by Bernardino Amico, a Franciscan monk in Jerusalem between1593-1597. Amico, in fact, copied a map made by another Franciscan monk, Antonio d'Angelis, who had served in Jerusalem a few years before; his map continued to be copied by generations of Christian map-makers.

The map does not identify the religious affiliation of the monuments with a cross or crescent, and calls the mosques on the Temple Mount – "The Pagan Church".

attachments.name: Jerusalem,  Dapper, Amsterdam 1677 'De Stadt Ierusalem zoot Hedendaeghs Bevonden wordt'.jpg
attachments.location: 62CF2583-19FF-9B73-7ED2-2E3C833E1F7F\Jerusalem,  Dapper, Amsterdam 1677 'De Stadt Ierusalem zoot Hedendaeghs Bevonden wordt'.jpg

children.name: :4: Mondhare's Map
children.data: This landscape drawn by L. Mondhare in 1770, portrays Ottoman Jerusalem as a city commanded by towering minarets and crescents in a surreal mixture of imagination and reality. Prominently situated towards the left of the map is the Dome of the Rock while in the center the Church of the Holy Sepulcher stands out clearly. At the front of the sketch is the Kidron River, usually a dry riverbed, appearing as a broad, rushing, European style river. The inscription at the bottom states that the City of David and Solomon is currently controlled by the Ottomans and notes the existence of a Franciscan monastery within the city.

attachments.name: Jerusalem, Mondhare,  Paris 1770, 'Jerusalem Ville Capitale de la Palestine sous David et Salomon'.jpg
attachments.location: F1A2E200-3903-B57D-F9ED-561C9A606EB0\Jerusalem, Mondhare,  Paris 1770, 'Jerusalem Ville Capitale de la Palestine sous David et Salomon'.jpg

children.name: A Dutch Map
children.data: This map was drawn in the Netherlands, following Ortelius's map of the Holy Land around 1600. The anonymous artist added to Ortelius' map a series of illustrations, including Jonah being tossed to the mouth of the big fish and Israelite figures crossing the desert. At the bottom right the twelve tribes are encamped in the Sinai Desert, and on the bottom right the Grotto of the Nativity in Bethlehem is depicted. Interestingly, the North in the compass rose is pointing to the south!

attachments.name: Palestine, Dutch, beginning of 17th century, 'De Caerte vant theylich land..'.jpg
attachments.location: 0711F4D9-F275-9116-0C43-AE1B48ADAD97\Palestine, Dutch, beginning of 17th century, 'De Caerte vant theylich land..'.jpg

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Seutter's Map
children.data: Matthaeus Seutter's map of Palestine was part of his atlas, which was popular in Europe in the 18th century. The map, based on a prototype made a century earlier by Sanson, aims to depict the Holy Land to the Christian European audience from the First Temple until the Roman period, covering the period of the events told in the Old and New Testament. Equally important, is the scene on the top left, showing Jesus exorcising a demon, watched from above by God and the Holy Spirit, with the Crucifixion in the background. On the bottom right the route of the Exodus from Egypt is depicted separately.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: Blaeu's Map
children.data:
In 1629, W.J. Blaeu printed a new world atlas containing 45 maps. One of these was a map of the Holy Land as seen by Moses from Mt. Nevo just before his death and after forty years of wandering with the Israelites in the desert.

The cartouche on the bottom right is surrounded by the figures of Moses and Aaron. In this image, Moses had just descended from Mt. Sinai with the Tablets and is shown according to Jerome's mistaken translation of Exodus 34:29, with horns over his head. Next to him stands Aaron, the High Priest, in his special attire and paraphernalia.

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: :1: The Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert
children.data: The story of Moses and the Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert is shown here in miniature drawings: on the left the Children of Israel are seen crossing the parted Red Sea, their following route through the desert being marked by a yellow trail. On the right the revelation at Mount Sinai, as well as the Tabernacle and the various camps of the Israelites are depicted.
children.chronologicalName: The Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert

children.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes
children.data: Jewish maps, though few and far between, represent the centrality of the Land of Israel in the history and hopes of the Jewish people. Traditional Jewish maps reflect two distinct trends in cartographic tradition: one group of maps follows  the original maps made by the prominent Bible commentator Rashi, while another follows Christian map models adapted to Jewish notions.

attachments.name: Map of The Land Israel,  Showing the Wanderings of the Israelites in the Desert,  Abraham ben Jacob, 17th cent.jpg
attachments.location: 03BA7521-8885-B14D-345A-0440CB69EB04\Map of The Land Israel,  Showing the Wanderings of the Israelites in the Desert,  Abraham ben Jacob, 17th cent.jpg

parent.name: Maps of The Holy Land in the Eran Laor collection

children.name: The Land of Israel -  European  Inspirations

parent.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes

children.name: :1: Shlomo of Helm's Map of the Land of Israel
children.data:
R. Shlomo of Helm (1717-1781) was a famous Jewish scholar and Rabbi in Poland. Although he was famous for his erudition in Jewish sources and law (Halakha), he chose extraordinarily to emphasize the importance of the study of Philosophy and Sciences alongside Jewish studies.

In the autograph manuscript of his book "Hug Ha-Aretz", recently purchased by the NLI, written in beautiful classical Hebrew language and in handsome calligraphic script, R. Shlomo drew a series of maps of the Land of Israel divided among the Tribes. Unlike the tradition following Rashi's maps, the legends in his maps prove that he was clearly inspired by the Christian maps of the Holy Land made by Adrichom and by Seutter.
children.chronologicalName: Shlomo of Helm's Map of the Land of Israel

parent.name: The Land of Israel -  European  Inspirations

children.name: :2: Schottlaender's map: A Harbinger of Zionism
children.data:
This lithograph, printed by Schottlaender in Breslau around 1900, is the last in a long line of maps, or tables, depicting Jewish pilgrimage sites and tombs of righteous men in the Holy Land. It is special in that it chooses to present only the most significant holy sites, omitting the rest. In their stead, the author elects to show the new colonies just established by Jews thus blending traditional views with the new Zionist movement!

The most prominent settlement in the map is Jerusalem; Safed appears above, to its left surrounded by many sacred tombs. The new Zionistic settlements are identified by the author as "colonie".

attachments.name: Panorama des heiligen landes, Schottlaender,  Breslau, 190-,  pal1134_b.jpg
attachments.location: 29A593B8-3FE8-D682-F394-B2EEC29B7D99\Panorama des heiligen landes, Schottlaender,  Breslau, 190-,  pal1134_b.jpg

children.chronologicalName: Schottlaender's map: A Harbinger of Zionism

parent.name: The Land of Israel -  European  Inspirations

children.name: The Land of Israel – the  Jewish Tradition
children.data:
This lovely hand-drawn map was drawn in the 19th century by an artist who claims that he copied it from the famous Jewish scholar, the Vilna Gaon (1720-1797).

The map follows an ancient tradition of mapping the borders of Land of Israel, as described in Numbers 34. This tradition commenced with Rashi, the greatest Jewish Biblical commentator, who lived in France in the 11th century.

Later tradition added the allotments of the 12 tribes, and cities and settlements which are represented here as European houses with tiled roofs. Jerusalem is depicted prominently with a tower beside it bearing the inscription "The Temple".

attachments.name: Palestine,  biblical borders and allotments of the tribes of Israel, mid nineteenth century.jpg
attachments.location: 6D3C4593-7543-E128-8DAC-F2605F00061D\Palestine,  biblical borders and allotments of the tribes of Israel, mid nineteenth century.jpg

parent.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes

children.name: Newton's Theological Papers
children.data:
Isaac Newton (1642-1727), the world-famous physicist and mathematician, was a central figure in the scientific revolution.

7500 papers, written in Newton's own hand, are preserved in the collections of the National Library of Israel. These divulge an unknown side of Newton's personality. Besides being a scientist, Newton was an avid (though unusual) Christian believer, who took  a special interest in the Scriptures, believing that a deep understanding of the text will allow him to unravel the secrets of the end of days and to compute the date of  Christ's Second Coming and the Apocalypse. Of special importance is Newton's deep interest in  the Jewish sources, and his view regarding the role they of the Jews  in the process of salvation.

attachments.name: Newton, treatise on the origin of religion and its corruption, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: A9033D67-7C48-B1E8-59A7-6F4E372E0EA7\Newton, treatise on the origin of religion and its corruption, NLI.jpg

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: :1: 2060 – The End of Days
children.data: In these notes, written on a letter bearing the remnants of its red seal wax, Newton calculated, based on the Book of Daniel 7:25, that the end of time will arrive in the year 2060.  Newton's calculations relied on his belief that the starting point is the year 800, a time when Charlemagne founded the Holy Roman Empire and the Pope's supremacy commenced. Here, Newton believed,  began the period of the "apostate's" church deepest corruption which will end in the Apocalyptic events such as plagues and fires, the terrible battle of Armageddon and eternal damnation of the wicked mentioned in the  Book of Revelation.

attachments.name: Newton,  Apocalyptic calculations regarding the year 2060, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: 6CBFE979-B4EF-E377-DEA7-2F096D47FC66\Newton,  Apocalyptic calculations regarding the year 2060, NLI.jpg

children.name: :2: Newton the Heretic
children.data:
Newton's extensive study of the Christian Doctrine brought him to the conclusion that the doctrine of the Trinity was a corruption of the original biblical doctrine. He believed that the Scriptures taught that God is one person and that this one person is the Father, while Christ is the literal Son of God, having no human father.

Newton hid his beliefs. Had his contemporaries known of them he would have been considered a heretic. He however, believed that he was the true Orthodox.

 

Citations from the 'Twelve Statements on God'

Par. 1 - The [word] God is nowhere in the scriptures used to signify more han the three persons at once.

Par. 3 – Whenever it is said in the scriptures that there is but one God, it is meant of the Father.

attachments.name: Isaac Newton, Rejector of the Trinity
Newton,  Twelve Statements on God, NLI.jpg

children.name: :3: Newton and the Jewish Temple
children.data:
Newton believed that the temple described in the prophecy of Ezekiel will materialize at the End of Days. He therefore invested much effort in studying matters related to the Jewish Temple and its rituals.

This trilingual manuscript written in Latin, Hebrew and Greek shows that Newton was familiar not only with the work of  scholars of his time but also with the ancient Jewish sources including the Mishna, the Zohar, the Talmud and many more.

On the third line from the top Newton copied in meticulous Hebrew script the words:

ברוך שם כבוד מלכותו לעולם ועד  - " - Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom for all eternity".

attachments.name: Newton, Fragments on the kingdoms of the European tribes, the Temple and the Jewish and Christian Churches, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: 4130AC26-0B7C-306D-58D1-87B4DD7C00BD\Newton, Fragments on the kingdoms of the European tribes, the Temple and the Jewish and Christian Churches, NLI.jpg

children.name: :_: What is The Talmud
children.data:
Talmud, the central text of rabbinic Judaism has influenced the lives of Jews no less, and perhaps much more than the Hebrew Bible. The Talmud (literally "study, learning") contains the teachings, the discussions and opinions of rabbis on a variety of subjects pertaining to Halakhah (Jewish law) and ethics, philosophy and history, to mention just a few.

The talmudic text, also known as Gemara (literally: tradition) is based on discussions which took place in Jewish academies between the third and the sixth centuries, in Palestine and in Babylonia. These discussions usually revolve around the Mishnah which was assembled in the beginning of the third century. The most popular and influential version of the Talmud is the Babylonian one, although a Palestinian version exists as well.

The Talmud, written in Hebrew and Aramaic has become the legal authority in rabbinic Judaism and is the basis for halakhic discourse. Maimonides' Mishneh Torah is a legal code summarizing Jewish law and is based mainly on the Talmud.

children.name: :4: Map of the Fifth and Sixth Trumpets
children.data: Newton's preoccupation with the Apocalypse of John elicited this realistic map of the Near East which illustrates the geography of the region in which the Apocalyptic events will occur. According to Revelation 9 four angels will be released on the Euphrates river and will punish the sinners. Newton believed that the Fifth Trumpet is Islam, and the Sixth – the Ottoman Empire and identified as these four angels in the Sultanates marked out on the map: Iconium, Damascus, Mosul and Miapharekin.

attachments.name: Newton, Map of the Fifth and Sixth Trumpets, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: BB7FB86D-54E0-57DD-EA6F-71CD5EFAE26B\Newton, Map of the Fifth and Sixth Trumpets, NLI.jpg

children.name: :5: Newton -  Shrewd Head of the Royal Mint
children.data:
Besides being a brilliant scientist and theologian, Newton was also displayed adroit skills as an administrator. In 1696 He was appointed Warden of the Royal Mint in London. In this capacity Newton wrote this letter to the tin mine owners, explaining to them through meticulous calculations that Her Majesty, Queen Anne, has already purchased from them much more tin than she can sell, leaving her with "dead stock" (surplus), which can only be sold at a loss.

He therefore announces his decision to end the contract with them.
children.chronologicalName: Newton -  Shrewd Head of the Royal Mint

children.name: :6: Newton the Alchemist (c. 1680)
children.data: Newton also took a deep interest in Alchemy. Although most of the Alchemical papers are in Cambridge, the NLI possesses one unique page. It is a part of Newton's copy of an English translation made in 1624 of the Exposition of the Hieroglyphical figures written by the famous French Alchemist Nicholas Flamel. Newton sketched Flamel's symbolic figures, and described in the text above their Alchemical role.

attachments.name: The Hieroglyphical figures of Nicholas Flammel explained  (early 1680s), NLI.jpg
attachments.location: 63A1DFAA-E53C-BB5B-35AF-0FE5825914EC\The Hieroglyphical figures of Nicholas Flammel explained  (early 1680s), NLI.jpg

parent.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

children.name: :1: Descent
children.data:
Abraham Shalom Yahuda (1877 – 1951) was born in Jerusalem to a respectable family. His father's family, which had arrived in Jerusalem from Baghdad,  descended from the famous Yosef ben Shushan, a Jewish minister at the court of Alfonso VIII (1155-1214) king of Castile, while his mother came from a  well-known German Jewish family. 

photograph: The Tolledo synagogue built by Yosef Ben-Shushan's son, one of A.S. Yahuda's forefathers. The Synagogue was later converted into a church by the name of Santa Maria la Blanca.

attachments.name: Synagoga Santa Maria La Blanca, Tolledo.JPG

children.name: :2: Education
children.data: From a very young age Yahuda mastered both Jewish studies as well as the Arabic language and other European languages. He specialized in classical Arabic literature and at the age of 17 he already published a book on the subject. He then continued his studies in Germany with important scholars in the field of Arabic and Islamic history.

attachments.name: Abraham Shalom Yahuda, portrait, G Krokorian studio, Jerusalem.jpg
attachments.location: 90F7942D-189C-1C8B-5601-5E0191DA085B\Abraham Shalom Yahuda, portrait, G Krokorian studio, Jerusalem.jpg

children.name: :3: From Madrid to Europe and the East
children.data: Between 1914-1922 Yahuda served as professor in Madrid. (In later years Yahuda wrote memoirs in Hebrew describing  his sojourn in Spain.) He then left Spain, and spent the years between 1922 and 1942 travelling all over Europe and the East. During these years Yahuda acquired many rare manuscripts and traded in them. Yahuda's great erudition in many fields, and especially in Islam, explains the superior manuscripts that he chose to acquire during his travels.
children.chronologicalName: From Madrid to Europe and the East

children.name: :4: America
children.data: In 1942 Yahuda received a position in the New School of Social Research in New-York, and from then on, until his death in 1951, spent most of his time on his research.

children.name: :5: The Yahuda Exquisite Manuscript Collection, Islamic manuscripts
children.data:
Yahuda bequeathed to the National Library of Israel  1184 exquisite eastern manuscripts in the field of Islamic religion, sciences, Arabic literature and Persian poetry. These include a unique collection of  over 100 rare manuscripts of the Qur'an, some very early ones (8th-10th centuries), and others which are beautifully illustrated.

 

Jewish manuscripts

Yahuda's collection of Jewish manuscripts includes the most beautiful existing manuscript of  Maimonides' Mishneh Torah 

and documents of the Jewish Community in Aragon, including a Privilege granted by King Alfonso V of Aragon  (1416-1438) to the nobleman Berenguer de Bardaxi , granting him permission to settle 30-40 Jewish families on his lands in Oliete, south of Zaragossa.

 

Other Manuscripts

Besides Newton's theological papers, the collection includes beautiful Books of Hours, letters of Napoleon Bonaparte, and many more.

attachments.location: 4ADAD622-F4FC-80AF-4CC4-D87C34B2D4AA\The Shirazi Qur'an, Iran, early 16th century, front page, NLI.jpg

children.chronologicalName: The Yahuda Exquisite Manuscript Collection, Islamic manuscripts

children.name: :1: Newton's Papers  - from 1727 to 1872
children.data: Upon Newton's death in Cambridge in 1727, his relatives, the Conduitts, claimed his papers. Newton's papers reflected an array of various interests and occupations: papers in Mathematics and Physics, documents written as part of his function as head of the Royal Mint and President of the Royal Society, and the less known and more intriguing papers on Theology, History and Alchemy.

parent.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

children.name: :2: Donation of the Papers to Cambridge, 1872 – 1936
children.data:
In 1872, one of Newton's descendants, the 5th Earl of Portsmouth, donated the papers to the University of Cambridge, in which Newton had studied and taught. The committee appointed by the University to review the papers, selected only Newton's scientific papers, not wanting to blemish his reputation as an enlightened intellectual and scientist.

The theological papers, as well as the alchemical and the historical papers were returned to the family.

Yahuda bequeathed his papers upon his death in 1951 to the National Library of Israel in Jerusalem, along with many other important and beautiful manuscripts of all sorts.

children.name: The NLI Islam Collection
children.data:
The National Library of Israel possesses a world renowned Islam and Middle East collection, reflecting the cultural heritage of Israel’s largest minority and the dominant culture of the Middle East. The literary traditions of Arabic and Persian are also part of the Jewish collective memory, since these were dominant languages for a large part of the Jewish people until the contemporary era.

The Library possesses more than 2,400 manuscripts in the Arabic script, primarily in the Arabic language, but also in Persian and Ottoman Turkish. The most distinguished set is from the Yahuda collection, comprising 1,184 rare and often exquisite manuscripts. Writings from all the major Islamic religious disciplines are present as well as literature, medicine, mathematics and the natural sciences.  Among the several hundred illustrated manuscripts of the collection, there are more than one hundred decorated Qur’ans from diverse locales – including 12th Spain. There also are numerous texts with miniature paintings, depicting scenes from the great works of Arabic and Persian epic literature, such as the Shah Nameh, and beloved love stories such as “Laila and Majnun.”

attachments.name: Jami, detail of Persian garden scene.jpg

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: Qur'an Manuscripts at NLI
children.data: This is a Qur’an section from 12th century Andalusia. It is the 29th section (of 30), written on parchment, which was mostly likely copied in 12th century Seville. The Arabic Andalusian script developed out of Kufic script. Although the script uses conventional vowels and punctuation, it references the early Kufic script by using a distinct yellow dot for the hamza instead of a letter. Displayed here is the end of Chapter 77, Surat al-Mursalat, and the end of the section.

children.name: :1: A Ninth Century Qur'an
children.data: Qur’an section from 9th century Qayrawan (in modern day Tunisia). Part of the third section (of seven), in Kufic, the oldest calligraphic script in Arabic. The manuscript represents an intermediate stage of the written Qur'an,  between the earliest texts that included only letters, and the completely punctuated and vowelized   text familiar today. In addition to the red dots representing vowels, variant readings are presented either using green or yellow dots. Shown here is the beginning of Chapter 11, Surat Hud.

children.name: The Book of Alexander the Great
children.data: The “Book of Honor”, from Nizami's Book of Alexander the Great. Nizami Ganjavi (d. 1209), the greatest of the medieval Muslim Persian poets, wrote a set of five epic romantic poems, including the two-part Book of Alexander: the Book of Honor, depicting Alexander's education and early military campaigns, and the Book of Fortune, relating his later development from a warrior to a philosopher and prophet. The manuscript, from 17th c. India, is opened to a scene of the young Alexander, cast with a halo, studying with his teacher, Aristotle (wearing white).

children.name: The Poem of the Prophet's Mantle
children.data: The Burdah poem, or “Poem of the Mantle,” was a famous poem written by Muhammad al-Busiri (d. 1265), based on the author’s mystical vision of the Prophet Muhammad. This highly decorated manuscript, which includes the poem and a commentary, was copied in Jerusalem by one of the most famous lexicographers of the medieval Arab world, Muhammad al-Fairuzabadi (d. 1414). Al-Fairuzabadi was the author of the Comprehensive Dictionary (“al-qamus al-muhit”), which was the most widely used Arabic dictionary until the modern period. He copied the manuscript during the ten years he spent studying in Jerusalem, prior to 1362.

attachments.name: Muhammad al-Busiri, Al-Burdah (poem of the Mantle), manuscript - mid 14th century .jpg
attachments.location: A644331A-76D0-F19B-F559-BCF92E098237\Muhammad al-Busiri, Al-Burdah (poem of the Mantle), manuscript - mid 14th century .jpg

children.name: :1: The Manuscript
children.data: Nur al-Din Jami’s “Gift to the Noble.” Jami (d. 1492), the last of the classical Persian poets, was a mystic linked to the Sufi Naqshbandi order in Herat (in modern Afghanistan). One of his most famous poems, “Gift to the Noble (or Gift of the Freemen),” is a collection of aphorisms and moral parables in rhymed poetic stanzas.  Jami presented this collection to the leader of the Naqshbandis, who was also known as “Lord of the Nobles/Freemen.” This manuscript was copied in 1484, just three years after Jami composed the poem. Yahuda Ms.Ar.1013

children.name: :2: The Persian Garden Miniatures
children.data: In addition to its historical importance, this manuscript includes two beautiful miniatures that were added later in the 18th century, simulating 15th century illustration styles. Shown here is a royal garden scene, from the manuscript’s opening page. On the right side, a prince and his entourage are standing by a flowing stream, while a gardener holding a hoe in the top right corner, enters through the garden’s gate. On the left side, courtiers stand near a spring, in which fish swim, and a shepherd plays his flute with his dog nearby.

children.name: The Story of the Shirazi Qur’an
:1: The Shirazi Qur’an
children.data: This Shirazi Qur’an, dating from the early 16th century, was most likely commissioned for the Safavid court in Tabriz, Iran. The Qur’an is richly illuminated with gold, lapis lazuli and dark orange and was clearly considered a precious manuscript. Shown here is the opening chapter of the Qur’an.

attachments.name: The Shirazi Qur'an, Iran, early 16th century, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: E85FC4C9-9F79-E3CF-CFC6-385532AADF7A\The Shirazi Qur'an, Iran, early 16th century, NLI.jpg

parent.name: The Story of the Shirazi Qur’an

children.name: :2: Between Shi‘a and Sunnah
children.data: Beyond its beauty, the manuscript carries a dramatic history. The original Shi‘i scribe included the line, “Ali is the beloved of God (‘Ali wali allah), in his concluding prayer. However, this reference to 'Ali, cousin and son in law of Muhammad, and his rightful successor according to Shiʿii Muslims, was covered over in gold paint when the Qur’an passed from Shi‘i to Sunni hands.

parent.name: The Story of the Shirazi Qur’an

children.name: :3: At the Hands of the Ottoman Sultan
children.data: From the smaller of the two seals on the manuscript’s front, we can surmise that the Qur’an passed into the hands of none other than the Ottoman Sultan Selim ibn Bayazid (r.1512-1520), who vanquished the Safavid Persians in the Battle of Chaldiran Valley, on the border of Persia and Azerbaijan, in August 1514, and then seized the treasures of Tabriz for his collection in Istanbul.

attachments.name: The Shirazi Qur'an, Iran, early 16th century, Two seals on the manuscript’s front, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: A2DCEFBF-C896-A2B3-79EB-898B91470F51\The Shirazi Qur'an, Iran, early 16th century, Two seals on the manuscript’s front, NLI.jpg

children.chronologicalName: At the Hands of the Ottoman Sultan

parent.name: The Story of the Shirazi Qur’an

children.name: :4: The Selim Nameh Manuscript
children.data: An outstanding  illuminated description of the Battle of Chaldiran Valley and its aftermath is found in another manuscript of the Islamic collection at the NLI. The Book of Selim (Selim Nameh), a Turkish epic poem on the heroic deeds of Sultan Selim, was composed shortly after his death by one of his companions, the Kurdish Emir Shukri Bey Biltisi, on commission from Selim’s son, Suleiman (known as “the Magnificent”).  This splendid manuscript, completed in 1524, includes a double-page miniature (121r-122v) depicting the battle.

attachments.name: Shukri Bey Biltisi, Selim Nameh (The Book of Selim), manuscript-1524, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: 91B48F92-D65D-CC3F-D13F-E59555B7EDAF\Shukri Bey Biltisi, Selim Nameh (The Book of Selim), manuscript-1524, NLI.jpg

parent.name: The Story of the Shirazi Qur’an

children.name: :5: Sultan Selim as the Defender of Islam
children.data: The miniature makes use of religious symbolism – Sultan Selim I, on horseback, is dressed in the mantle of the Prophet Muhammad, implying that it is he who defends true Islam, that is, the Sunni tradition. Above him, a flag flies with the legend, “Victory from Allah and redemption at hand.” There is no indication that the Shah and his army are Muslims, but rather, they are dressed like pre-Islamic Persian soldiers.
children.chronologicalName: Sultan Selim as the Defender of Islam

children.name: The Torah Scroll from Spain
children.data: This is the story of the fascinating journey of a Torah scroll which was made in Spain in the 14th or 15th century,  travelled to Rhodes with the Jewish exiles from Spain, was hidden during the Nazi occupation in a Muslim mosque, and was brought to the National Library of Israel by descendants of the community of Rhodes in 1999.

attachments.name: Reading the Torah (Genesis), Spanish-Jewish liturgy, Greece.mp3

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: Other Torah manuscripts at the NLI
children.data: The NLI houses a large collection of Torah manuscripts. We present to you here some of the finest of them, Scrolls as well as Codices.

attachments.name: A Damascus Crown, France or Germany, 13th century.jpg
attachments.location: 7F13F425-9474-7539-509D-FEDE3A2F8619\A Damascus Crown, France or Germany, 13th century.jpg

children.name: :1: Other Torah Scrolls at NLI
children.data:
The National Library of Israel preserves several other ancient Torah scrolls, among them a scroll from Yemen, dating from around 1050-1150. The scroll contains large fragments of the Book of Numbers.

Another Torah scroll from Germany dates from the 15th century.

attachments.name: A Torah Scroll from Yemen,  11th-12th centuries.jpg

parent.name: Other Torah manuscripts at the NLI

children.name: :2: The Damascus Crown (Keter) from Spain
children.data: There are several exquisite Jewish Bible codices at the NLI known as the 'Damascus Crowns'. One of these was written in Burgos, Spain, and dates from around 1260. After 1492 the Jewish exiles from Spain brought the Burgos Bible with them to Damascus where it was used by the local Jewish community for hundreds of years. In 1940, in the wake of the political turmoil in Syria, it disappeared.  After 22 years, in 1962, it was suddenly presented and offered to the highest bidder on a public auction in London.  Later that year the Burgos Bible was purchased by the National Library of Israel.  The Manuscript is beautifully and delicately illuminated.

attachments.name: A Damascus Crown with Cantillation (chanting marks).jpg
The Damascus Crown from Burgos, end of Genesis and beginning of Exodus.jpg
attachments.location: 277C7CA7-F6EA-FFD0-D111-E975E0D01409\The Damascus Crown from Burgos, end of Genesis and beginning of Exodus.jpg

parent.name: Other Torah manuscripts at the NLI

children.name: What is a Keter?
children.data: The name Keter, meaning crown in Hebrew, originally referred to one very special codex of the Torah, which was written with punctuation and cantillation marks in the city of Tiberias (Eretz Israel) by Aaron ben Asher. Receiving later Maimonides' approbation as the most precise edition of the text, it became the most cherished manuscript of the Torah. The manuscript, which ended up in Aleppo (Syria), was rescued by Jews and brought to Israel and is now on permanent display at the Israel Museum.  Over time, the term Keter came to include any codex of the Bible or one of its components which includes vocalization and masoretic marks.

children.name: :3: Journey of the Edel Torah
children.data:
The Scroll seen here was donated to the NLI by the Adini-Edel family.

Unlike the Torah scrolls usually used in Synagogues, this is a miniature scroll,

written in micrographic script.

It was either written or owned by a well-known Jewish scholar from eastern

Europe by the name of Rabbai Judah Edel (1757 – 1828), who in his capacity as a

preacher travelled much and needed a compact version of the Torah to take with

him. After it was donated to the library it turned out that one of the library's most

experienced manuscript experts was a descendent of Rabbai Edel.

attachments.name: Benjamin Richler and the Edel Torah.jpg

parent.name: Other Torah manuscripts at the NLI

children.name: Torah Introduction
children.data:
The Torah

The Torah, the first five books of the Old Testament, is the oldest and most sacred text of the Jews. 

It is believed traditionally to have been given by God to Moses on Mount Sinai. Modern scholarship maintains that it was written by various authors throughout several centuries, probably from the ninth century BCE onward.

attachments.name: Receiving the Torah, Prayer book, North Italy, c.1450, NLI.jpg
attachments.location: AC791DF6-12F4-259A-66B5-2CF6E747A6A1\Receiving the Torah, Prayer book, North Italy, c.1450, NLI.jpg

children.name: :1:  Reading The Torah
children.data: The reading begins on Genesis 1, on the first Saturday which follows  the Jewish High Holidays, and in the course of one year the whole Torah is read.  Every Jewish Synagogue has at least one Torah Scroll, which is housed in a special sacred cabinet called the Ark. The ark is veiled by an embroidered curtain called Parochet or is closed off by doors.

attachments.name: Yaakov Fux Reading the Torah, NLI

children.name: :2: Making the Torah Scroll
children.data: The Torah used in the Synagogue is copied on specially prepared vellum or parchment by a scribe called Sofer Stam who specializes in copying sacred texts according to the ritual laws; it is sewn together in one piece and rolled up around two rollers with handles.

children.name: :3: Torah Accessories
children.data: There are special accessories such as:

children.name: Breastplate
children.data: An ornate silver and gold breastplate with the image of the Ten Commandments, often with medallions containing the names of the donors attached.

children.name: The Coat/Case
children.data:
The girdle that binds it, and an embroidered mantle

or alternatively, a case that covers it

children.name: The Reading Pointer
children.data: The silver hand which serves as a reading pointer

children.name: The Finials
children.data: The crown or finials which embellish it

children.name: :1: From Spain to Jerusalem
children.data:
The NLI houses various such Torah Scrolls. The Scroll we present here, which had belonged to the Kahal Shalom Synagogue in Rhodes, is actually one of the less impressive to look at; 

it is in fact disintegrating and according to our conservationist - is actually beyond repair.

Although the NLI possesses finer ones - in a much better state of preservation, we chose to present it because of the fascinating story of its wanderings throughout the Mediterranean and the hardships it had encountered until its arrival at our library in the summer of 1999.

This story represents the history of the Jewish people through the ages in a nutshell.

 

Photograph of Coat: The inscription reads 'Donated in memory of our dear brothers who died in sanctification of the divine name, by Hayyim and Lilly Noterika'.

children.name: :2:  From Spain to Rhodes
children.data:
Our Torah Scroll dates to the 14th or 15th century.  It is written upon brown colored vellum made up of 81 sheets which altogether are 45.5 meters long. It was almost certainly made in Spain for one of the Jewish communities there, as the paleographic style is that of the Spanish Jewish tradition. Additionally, on one of the rollers appears the name of the owner – Yaakov ben Abraham Mar Hayyim, a member of a well-known Jewish family in Spain before the expulsion of the Jews in 1492.

The attached songs are representative of the rich culture of the Sepharadic jews, which were exiled in 1492 and spread all around Europe.

attachments.name: A Hebrew-Spanish (Ladino) song, Una Pastora, Isaac Levy.mp3
attachments.location: 9DE4306F-1BA6-883F-87D0-E57A0AC68CD9\A Hebrew-Spanish (Ladino) song, Una Pastora, Isaac Levy.mp3

attachments.name: An Israeli song based on a Ladino song, 'Im Yesh Ey Sham Rahok' (If there is a place far far away).mp3
attachments.location: 9DE4306F-1BA6-883F-87D0-E57A0AC68CD9\An Israeli song based on a Ladino song, 'Im Yesh Ey Sham Rahok' (If there is a place far far away).mp3

children.name: :3:  Kahal Shalom Synagogue - Rhodes
children.data:
The cherished Torah Scroll was taken by its owners from Spain upon their expulsion, when Jews from Spain wandered throughout the Mediterranean basin in search for a new home. The owners of this Scroll, a family or perhaps a congregation, finally settled down on the island of Rhodes, and the Scroll found its way to the Kahal-Shalom Synagogue. The synagogue was founded in 1577 in the city of Rhodes, which like the rest of the island had been under the rule of the Ottoman Turks since 1522. The Kahal Shalom synagogue was one of six synagogues which existed in the city of Rhodes, where a vital Jewish community lived in its own quarter – the Juderia

Like the other Spanish Jewish communities which settled in the Mediterranean, the Jewish community of Rhodes spoke Ladino – a special dialect of Castilian Spanish mixed with Hebrew, and then also Turkish and Greek.

attachments.name: Piyyut. Jewish liturgical poem, Thessalonica, Spanish-Hebrew and Hebrew.mp3
attachments.location: F8D25BDD-4C45-9623-9A0D-6A7188E4C10A\Piyyut. Jewish liturgical poem, Thessalonica, Spanish-Hebrew and Hebrew.mp3

attachments.location: F8D25BDD-4C45-9623-9A0D-6A7188E4C10A\Sepharadic song for the end of Sturday, Smyrna.mp3

children.name: :4: The Nazi Occupation Period
children.data:
The Scroll served the community of Kahal-Shalom for over 400 years, until the island was occupied by the Nazis, and most of its Jews were transported to Auschwitz and were exterminated. From the 2000 members of the Island's Jewish community, 1673 were deported. Of these, only 151 survived. 

The Torah Scroll was saved through the good relations of the Jewish and Muslim communities, as well as through an intriguing family connection: the Scroll was deposited with the Mufti of Rhodes, Suleyman Kasiloglou, just a few days before the deportation on July 25th 1944.  Kasiloglu's father in law was Jewish, what may explain why the Jewish community trusted him with its most valuable possession.  Kasiloglou hid the Torah under the pulpit of the Morad Reis mosque. .

The Scroll remained rolled on the last portion which was read in the Synagogue, "Parashat Pinhas",on the Sabbath of July 15th 1944. This same part in the scroll was heavily damaged by mildew due to the conditions in the hiding place.

children.name: :5: Final Stop - NLI
children.data: After the war was over the Scroll was returned to the few survivors of the community, and the honorary president of the community, Mr. Moshe Sauriano gave them to the Benatar family, to be brought to the NLI, in memory of the Jews from Rhodes who were exterminated.

children.name: The Unique de Lonzano Kabbalah Manuscript
children.data: In 2010 a unique manuscript containing a rare collection of Kabbalah lessons. some of which were unknown until now, was discovered in an attic in Bnei-Berak, Israel. The manuscript, central to the understanding of the Lurianic Kabbalah, was written by Rabbi Menahem de Lonzano in 1610, exactly 400 years before it was discovered in the attic. De Lonzano, an important scholar and a colourful figure, recorded the lessons from two famous students of R. Isaac Luria (1534-1572), the most significant figure in the Kabbalah movement in Safed (in the Land of Israel), only a few decades after they were given.

parent.name: The National Library of Israel as a Memory Deposit

children.name: Gershom Scholem and his Library at NLI

parent.name: The Unique de Lonzano Kabbalah Manuscript

children.name: :1: Who was Gershom Scholem (1897-1982)?
children.data:
During the 20th century the Kabbalah aroused renewed interest in the academic world. Modern research of the Kabbalah was led by Prof. Gershom Scholem at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

Professor Gershom Scholem was born in Berlin in 1897 and immigrated to Palestine, then under the British Mandate, in 1923. Scholem began his career as the curator of the Judaica Department of the then Jewish National and University Library, subsequently becoming Professor of Kabbalah at the newly established Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Scholem published some 700 scholarly books and articles on all aspects of Jewish Mysticism during his lifetime.

parent.name: Gershom Scholem and his Library at NLI

children.name: :2: The Scholem Collection at NLI
children.data: At his request, his enormous book collection (some 25,000 titles) was transferred to the National Library upon his death in 1982, and  the Gershom Scholem Collection for Kabbalah Research was instituted. This special reading room, which today contains approximately 35,000 titles, is one of the outstanding treasures of the National Library, serving as the leading center for Kabbalah research in the world. here that scholars pour over the great works of Jewish Mysticism, such as De Lonzano's manuscript, and paving the way for continued academic research in coming generations.

children.name: Who was Menahem de Lonzano
children.data: Menahem de Lonzano (1550 – 1624) was a scholar, well- versed in many fields. Born in Italy or in Istanbul, Turkey, he moved to the Land of Israel, first to Jerusalem in 1575, then to Safed, and again toTurkey, Egypt and Italy, only to return to Jerusalem in 1618, where  he died in 1624. Although ill, crippled and almost blind, he was not deterred from composing books in which he attacked his fellow Rabbis. He was therefore often censured, and constantly had to wander destitute, from one place to the other. He was especially known as a scholar of the Mesorah which aimed at determining the precise text of the Torah, and was the author of many original compositions related to Jewish sources, Kabbalah, and Hebrew poetry and grammar.

parent.name: The Unique de Lonzano Kabbalah Manuscript

children.name: :1: The Book of "Derushim"
children.data: De Lonzano's manuscript contains "Derushim" or  lessons which he recorded from the writings of two famous Kabbalists from Safed, R. Hayyim Vital and R. Joseph b. Tabul, who passed on the mystical teachings of their teacher, the famous Rabbi Isaac Luria also known as The Ari. The book, 200 pages long, is full of De Lonzano's often quite critical comments. One of the newly discovered lessons, which is especially important, is Luria's Lesson on the Primordial Man as passed on by Rabbi Hayyim Vital.

children.name: :2: What is The Lesson on the Primordial Man
children.data: This lesson is a basic exposition of the Ari's teaching regarding the process of creation.  According to this lesson/discourse God began the process of creation by "contracting" (Tzimtzum) his infinite light in order to allow for a vacuum in which finite and seemingly independent realms could exist. At this point time began and the root of “strict justice” (din) was secreted into this vacuum, mixed with the remnants of Divine Light still remaining in it. The goal of humanity is to salvage these spiritual lights and so bring to the restoration (tikkun) of the spiritual lights which have fallen under the domination of the forces of evil called “shells” (kelippot).

parent.name: The Unique de Lonzano Kabbalah Manuscript

children.name: :1: The Discovery of the Manuscript
children.data: In 2010 a member of the Hasidut of the Gur Rebbe found in his attic an anonymous manuscript. The book was not disposed of previously by his grandfather only because it contained the stamp of the first Rebbe of Radomsk, Rabbi Shlomo Ha-Cohen Rabinowitz (1801-1866). Curious about the value of the manuscript, the grandson contacted a dealer, who in his turn consulted an expert. To his surprise, the expert recognized the distinct writing of De Lonzano, realizing that he was holding a unique and treasured  autograph.

children.name: :2: When and Where was it written?
children.data:
Menahem de Lonzano did not note at the end of his manuscript, as authors often did, neither the place nor the time in which he wrote it. Yet in one place he noted that "the exile has lasted 370 years after the sixth millennium…Menahem D"L". This meant that the manuscript was copied  370 years after the creation, which is the year 1610 CE, exactly 400 years before it was rediscovered!

As for the place, it is most probable that it was copied in Egypt, as De Lonzano mentions negotiations with a one of the great scholars living in Egypt at that time.
children.chronologicalName: When and Where was it written?

children.name: :_: What is the Hasidut?
children.data:
Hasidut is a popular mystical mass movement in Judaism which was influenced by the ideas of the Kabbalah. The Hasidut stresses the innate ability of every person to achieve closeness to God through intense prayer, dance, music and other various ritual activities.

Beginning with a small group gathered around the charismatic Rabbi known as the "Baal Shem Tov" ("Master of the Good Name") (c. 1700-1760), this trend went on to conquer most of the Jewish Communities of Eastern Europe.

The Hasidim, as they are known, are easily recognizable by their distinctive dress, and some of their leaders, known as "Rebbes" have become world famous, such as the late Rabbi Menahem Mendel Schneerson (1902-1994) of the Lubavitch group (Chabad), some of whose followers even revere him as the Messiah.

children.name: What is the Kabbalah?
children.data:
Literally meaning "tradition" or "reception", Kabbalah is the traditional term for the medieval esoteric teachings of Judaism and for Jewish mysticism. Although it has much earlier roots, the term Kabbalah  refers usually to the discipline which developed in Provence and  Cataluña from  the second half of the 12th century.

 Following the Jewish expulsion from Spain in 1492, a new trend of the Kabbalah, the Lurianic Kabbalah, developed in Safed,  a town in 16th-century Ottoman Palestine, called by the Jews The Land of Israel.

children.name: :1: The Origins of  Jewish Mysticism
children.data: The roots of the Kabbalah go back to early esoteric Jewish literature such as the Heavenly Sanctuaries Literature (Hekhalot literature), Work of the Chariot (Ma'aseh Merkava), The Book of Creation (Sefer Yetzira); this literature itself originates in earlier sources going back to the 1st-2ed century CE.

children.name: :2: The Book of Splendor – Sefer Ha-Zohar
children.data:
The book of the Zohar, the central opus of the Kabbalah, was composed by Rabbi Moshe de Leon in Guadalajara between 1280 - 1286, but is believed by some scholars to have been written by a circle of authors.

The book purports to have been written by Rabbi Shimeon Bar Yohai, a Jewish sage of the second century, who while hiding from the Roman persecutions in a cave for thirteen years studied the Torah, inspired by the prophet.

The Zohar is a mystical commentary on the Torah (Pentateuch).

It revolves round two axes: one - the mysteries of the emanations of God, called the Sefirot, which are reflected in many symbols in the created world; the other - the situation of the Jew and his fate in this world and in the world of souls. The Zohar's major interest was a creation of an alternative reality where redemption replaces exile. Human action is thus seen as a vital contribution in the cosmic struggle between exile and redemption.

children.name: :3: From Spain to Safed : The Lurianic Kabbalah
children.data: Following the national trauma of the expulsion from Spain in 1492, Jews began to search for signs indicating the arrival of the awaited Jewish Messiah. In the 1500s the community of Safed, in the Galilee (the northern part of the Land of Israel), became the center of Jewish mystical, exegetical, legal and liturgical developments.

children.name: :4: The New Center in Safed
children.data: The school of Safed started with R. Joseph Caro, R. Shlomo Alkabetz, and R. Moshe Cordovero between 1535 and 1572, and culminated with Isaac Luria, its most influential leader.  While earlier Kabbalah centered on the return of man to the wellspring of his life through the contemplation of the upper worlds, the Safed mystics combined the Kabbalistic doctrine and practice with Messianic and apocalyptic trends.

children.name: :5:The Spread of the Kabbalah of Safed
children.data:
Later on Safed Kabbalah spread to Egypt, Turkey and Italy, and then to Jewish centers all over the Jewish Diaspora. 

In the 17th and 18th centuries Safed Kabbalah and Sefer ha-Zohar generated the messianic movement known as Sabbateanism. In Eastern Europe it stimulated a special movement called the Hasidut.

children.chronologicalName: The Spread of the Kabbalah of Safed

children.name: :6: An Esoteric Doctrine?
children.data:
The Kabbalah in general, and especially the Zohar, was considered by many a doctrine which can be correctly understood only by scholars who are well versed in the Jewish sources. After Sabbateanism, Kabbalah's delving into basic questions regarding the nature of the divine caused it to be conceived as a dangerous doctrine which may lead simple believers astray. It was thus usually forbidden to people below the age of forty and to those who were not learned.

The expansion of Kabbalah was much assisted by the invention of print, overcoming the restrictions which had been imposed on its dissemination and study.

children.name: :1: Christian Kabbalah
children.data: From the Renaissance onwards Jewish Kabbalah texts entered non-Jewish culture. The Kabbalistic tradition was adopted by Western Esoteric tendencies. Christian intellectuals developed an interest in Kabbalah. Yochanan Alemanno (1435-after 1504), the Italian Jewish humanist translated Kabbalistic texts to Latin and influenced the Italian philosopher Pico della Mirandola (1463-1494), who in turn was instrumental in spreading Kabbalistic ideas. Syncretistic traditions of “Christian Kabbalah” and “Hermetic Kabbalah” developed independently, reading the Jewish texts as universal ancient wisdom.

children.name: :2: Hermetic Kabbalah
children.data:
With the decline of Christian Kabbalah in the Age of Reason, Hermetic Kabbalah continued as a central underground tradition in Western esotericism. The adoption of Kabbalah by 18th century Western Esoteric tendencies was instrumental in creating the dualistic lexicon which paved the way to the French Revolution.

Through these non-Jewish associations with magic, alchemy and divination, Kabbalah acquired some popular occult connotations which were forbidden within Judaism. Today, many publications on Kabbalah belong to the non-Jewish New Age and occult traditions of Kabbalah rather than giving an accurate picture of Judaic Kabbalah.
